Authors: Segall R.R.
Title: A new EPA method: Leak detection beyond LDAR
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards, Measurement Technology Group (E143-02), Research Triangle Park, NC 27711, United States
Authors with affiliations: Segall, R.R., U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards, Measurement Technology Group (E143-02), Research Triangle Park, NC 27711, United States
Abstract: EPA's Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards efforts in the optical remote sensing field over the past several years have focused on: development and application of Smart LDAR for use in the leak detection and repair (LDAR) programs mandated by Federal rules regulating the refinery and chemical process industries; and validation of the Radial Plume Mapping (RPM) approach for identification of and measurement of flux from fugitive and area source emissions. RPM and some of the other process area scale remote sensing measurements have the ability not only to identify process areas with significant emissions, but can also quantify those emissions. They can locate and quantify emissions beyond the specific process equipment that are monitored under LDAR programs. The emissions flux measurements can be used with receptor models to determine potential impacts on surrounding communities. Quantification of emissions also allows facilities, regulatory agencies, and others to make more informed decisions regarding where to focus repair and/or control resources or requirements based on considerations such as product savings, air quality impacts, and cost/benefit analyses. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AWMA's 99th Annual Conference and Exhibition (New Orleans, LA 6/20-23/2006).
Author Keywords: Emissions test methods; FTIR; Fugitive emissions; LDAR; Optical remote sensing; TDL; UV-DOAS

Authors: Şengül M.
Title: Carbon capture and geological storage
Source title: Turkish Journal of Oil and Gas
Affiliations: Schlumberger Carbon Services, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Şengül, M., Schlumberger Carbon Services, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Reducing CO2 atmospheric concentrations by capturing emissions from the point sources and then storing them in subsurface reservoirs is thought to be a reliable solution until emission-free energy sources are developed and viable. The current options for captured CO2 utilization are: EOR, enhanced coal bed methane recovery, enhanced gas recovery, etc. Industry expertise also is being tapped in CO2 projects across Europe, China, India, US, and Australia, including major EU proposals under the Framework Program Six and the Australian CO2CRC Otway Project. These projects address pertinent issues in CO2 capture and storage such as site selection, storage monitoring and verification techniques, developing local CO2 storage sites from hydrogen- and power-generation plants, and industry training. Site selection, reservoir characterization, modeling of storage and long term leakage monitoring techniques and selected CO2 geological storage projects are presented.

Authors: Sengul M.
Title: CO2 sequestration - A safe transition technology
Source title: 8th SPE International Conference on Health, Safety and Environment in Oil and Gas Exploration and Production 2006
Affiliations: Schlumberger Carbon Services, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Sengul, M., Schlumberger Carbon Services, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Fossil fuel fired plants are responsible for the one third of the carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions which thought to be a major contributor to the current rise in the Earth's surface temperature. Reducing CO2 atmospheric concentrations by capturing emissions at the source - power plants or chemical units - and then storing them in subsurface reservoirs is thought by many scientists to be a reliable solution until emission-free energy sources are developed and viable. The current options for captured CO2 utilization are; Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR), Enhanced Coal Bed Methane Recovery (ECBM), Enhanced Gas Recovery (EGR), Food processing applications, Mineral products, Fertilizer manufacture, Algae growth promoter, Enhanced plant growth. The capture and storage of CO2 continues to accelerate as new projects are initiated and existing projects confirm the development scenarios. A crucial element in CO2 storage is reliable monitoring of CO 2 migration behavior and storage volumes. An innovative seismic monitoring techniques, has recently been awarded a U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) project that will examine the application of time-lapse (4D) seismic technology and advanced reservoir simulation to optimize CO2 EOR operations. Well design, cementing, completions techniques and long life cycle mechanical integrity assurance are currently subject of many R&D projects. Industry expertise also is being tapped in CO2 projects across Europe and in Australia, including four major EU proposals under the Framework Program Six and the Australian CO2CRC Orway Project. These projects address pertinent issues in CO2 capture and storage such as site selection, storage monitoring and verification techniques, developing local CO2 storage sites from hydrogen- and power-generation plants, and industry training. In our paper framework of CO2 sequestration and vital aspects such as; site selection, reservoir characterization, modeling of storage and long term leakage monitoring techniques will be illustrated. Copyright 2006. Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Atmospherics; Fossil fuel power plants; Particulate emissions; Reaction kinetics; Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR); Sequestration; Subsurface reservoirs; Surface temperature; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Senguler I., Dagistan H.
Title: Importance of the lignite for energy in Turkey
Source title: 23rd Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference, PCC - Coal-Energy, Environment and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Mineral Research and Exploration, 06520 Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Senguler, I., Mineral Research and Exploration, 06520 Ankara, Turkey; Dagistan, H., Mineral Research and Exploration, 06520 Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Energy is the main input for industrialization and development. In electrical power generation, the share of thermal plants is 64%. Because of their low capacity and high initial investment cost renewable energy sources are not preferred. Since the coal resources comprise 27% of all the energy sources, it will continue to take a role in the 21st Century. 1.75% of these resources are located in Turkey and most of the electrical power generation is based on thermal power stations. Most of the known lignite deposits in Turkey are of low calorific value, high percentage of ash, volatile matter, moisture and sulphur. Almost 75% of the total reserves are with a calorific value of below 2500 kcal/kg. 17% are between 2500 and 3000 kcal/kg. While only the 8% are over 3000 kcal/kg. Therefore, it is inevitable that the majority of such lignites which are feasible technically and economically for exploitation must be enriched by washing before marketing. Total installed capacity of based on lignite thermal power plants is 6390 MW in Turkey. In addition to 1760 MW (Can and Elbistan) is under testing. It is planned to have thermal power plants with capacities of power 13810 MW in 2010 and 16060 in 2020. Coal exploration studies will be accelerated to correspond the energy deficiency of Turkey. General Directorate of Mineral Research and Exploration of Turkey (MTA) will carry out a series of coal exploration projects in different regions of Turkey. As a result of these studies including drilling activities, the coal reserves will have been increased importantly. United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) regulations stipulates that the green gas emissions should be dropped to 1990's level. Therefore new combustion technologies are required for energy resources. The thermal power plant in Can, Canakkale, capacity of power 2×160 MW with fluidized bed combustion technology will be a good example for the future use of this application. Turkey possesses a large lignite potential with 8.3 billion tons. New combustion technologies and coal mining applications will make this potential more attractive in the near future. The sensibility to the environmental problems in Turkey can be taken as a guarantee that we will not face the environmental problems industrialized countries had faced before. We should not forget that "a living society is one that obtains its current needs without destroying the belongings of the next generations".
Index Keywords: Calorific value; Electric power generation; Fluidized bed combustion; Power plants; Renewable energy resources; Coal mining; Thermal power stations; Volatile matter; Lignite

Authors: Shadbegian R.J., Gray W.B.
Title: Assessing multi-dimensional performance: Environmental and economic outcomes
Source title: Journal of Productivity Analysis
Affiliations: University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth, Dartmouth, MA, United States; National Center for Environmental Economics, USEPA, Washington, DC, United States; Economics Department, Clark University, 950 Main Street, Worcester, MA 01610, United States; NBER, 1050 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shadbegian, R.J., University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth, Dartmouth, MA, United States, National Center for Environmental Economics, USEPA, Washington, DC, United States; Gray, W.B., Economics Department, Clark University, 950 Main Street, Worcester, MA 01610, United States, NBER, 1050 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: This study examines economic performance, environmental performance, and regulatory activity for plants in three industries: pulp and paper, oil, and steel. Stochastic frontier production function models show significant deviations from production efficiency. Older plants are less efficient in production, but perform no worse on emissions. Plants spending more on pollution abatement tend to do worse on both production efficiency and emissions. Stricter local regulatory pressure is associated with somewhat lower emissions, but has mixed effects on production efficiency. Positive correlations between SUR residuals for emissions and production efficiency suggest unmeasured plant-level characteristics that drive both economic and environmental performance. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2006.
Author Keywords: Efficiency; Emissions; Productivity; Regulation

Authors: Shafer M.A.
Title: The role of intermediary organizations and knowledge communities in bridging barriers
Source title: 86th AMS Annual Meeting
Affiliations: Oklahoma Climatological Survey, 100 E. Boyd Street, Norman, OK, 73019, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shafer, M.A., Oklahoma Climatological Survey, 100 E. Boyd Street, Norman, OK, 73019, United States
Abstract: Does a cultural divide separate scientists from the broader community in which they live? This concept, proposed by C.P. Snow in 1959, has driven studies and reform movements within the scientific community for more than two decades. Calls to make science more relevant and to bridge barriers have been made. The study described here addresses this cultural divide in the context of drought policy. Its goal is to examine whether such a cultural divide exists and if so, what mechanisms facilitate interaction across this divide. This study was conducted between the summer of 2004 and spring of 2005. More than fifty individuals, representing both the scientific and state-level policy communities, were interviewed. Questions focused upon how scientists conducted and communicated their research, and information sources upon which policymakers draw for advice on creating state drought plans. The study used a communications model, consisting of a producer (scientists), a message, and a receptor (policy-makers). The two cultures barrier did not seem to be a significant factor in this process. While little direct communication between scientists and top policymakers was found, routine communication at lower levels of state organizations assured the effective flow of information into the policy planning process. Drought and climate information was communicated effectively to the policy community and utilized appropriately in creating or updating state-level drought plans. An additional component, intermediary organizations that help to integrate and reformat information, is included. Findings suggest that these intermediary organizations are a key component in facilitating interaction between the two communities. Scientists, intermediary organizations, and technical staff from state agencies operate together in knowledge communities, in which information is shared for development of state policy.
Index Keywords: Climate information; Direct communications; Information sources; Key component; Knowledge communities; Policy community; Policy makers; Policy planning; Scientific community; Significant factors; State agencies; State policy; Technical staff; Drought; Research; Societies and institutions

Authors: Shafer M.M., Schauer J.J., Copan W.G., Peter-Hoblyn J.D., Sprague B.N.
Title: Investigation of platinum and cerium from use of a FBC
Source title: SAE Technical Papers
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, Environmental Technology and Technology, Wisconsin State Laboratory of Hygiene, 660 North Park Street, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Clean Diesel Technologies, Inc., 300 Atlantic Street, Stanford, CT 06901, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shafer, M.M., University of Wisconsin, Environmental Technology and Technology, Wisconsin State Laboratory of Hygiene, 660 North Park Street, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Schauer, J.J., University of Wisconsin, Environmental Technology and Technology, Wisconsin State Laboratory of Hygiene, 660 North Park Street, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Copan, W.G., Clean Diesel Technologies, Inc., 300 Atlantic Street, Stanford, CT 06901, United States; Peter-Hoblyn, J.D., Clean Diesel Technologies, Inc., 300 Atlantic Street, Stanford, CT 06901, United States; Sprague, B.N., Clean Diesel Technologies, Inc., 300 Atlantic Street, Stanford, CT 06901, United States
Abstract: Fuel-borne catalysts (FBC) have demonstrated efficacy as an important strategy for integrated diesel emission control. The research summarized herein provides new methodologies for the characterization of engine-out speciated emissions. These analytical tools provide new insights on the mode of action and chemical forms of metal emissions arising from use of a platinum and cerium based commercial FBC, both with and without a catalyzed diesel particulate filter. Characterization efforts addressed metal solubility (water, methanol and dichloromethane) and particle size and charge of the target species in the water and solvent extracts. Platinum and cerium species were quantified using state-of-the-art high resolution plasma mass spectrometry. Liquid- chromatography-triple quad mass spectrometry techniques were developed to quantify potential parent Pt-FBC in the PM extracts. Speciation was examined for emissions from cold and warm engine cycles collected from an engine dynamometer. Water soluble platinum (6-hour extractions, 0.45 μm filtered) species represented a small fraction (2.8 ± 1.5%) of total aerosol-associated platinum. A large fraction of the water soluble platinum (44 ± 8%) was present as colloidal-sized particles. A similar fraction (54 ± 6%) of soluble cerium was retained on the ultrafilters. The fraction of platinum associated with the PM that has the potential to form truly dissolved (<10 kDa; ∼2nm) species averaged 1.5 ± 0.3%. Using ion-chromatographic methods it was determined that from 33 to 54% (41.5 ± 6.8%) of the <10 kDa -sized platinum species were anionic in character, while in contrast virtually all (97.5 ± 1.2%) of the cerium species were cationic or neutral in nature. Methanol extractions (24-hour Soxhlet, 0.45 μm filtered) released significantly more platinum (28 ± 1.4% of total) and DCM extractions significantly less platinum (0.66 ± 0.12% of total) than in water extractions. The parent Pt-FBC was not detectable in either methanol or DCM extracts of the diesel PM. The general speciation characteristics of FBC-platinum revealed in this study are consistent with findings of other studies of emissions from gasoline/diesel catalysts and those of environmental reservoirs. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Cerium; Chromatographic analysis; Dichloromethane; Emission control; Engines; Extraction; Filters (for fluids); Liquid chromatography; Mass spectrometry; Methanol; Organic solvents; Particle size; Platinum compounds; Reservoirs (water); Catalyzed diesel particulate filters; Chromatographic methods; Diesel emission control; Environmental reservoirs; Fuel-borne catalysts; Metal solubility; Plasma mass spectrometry; Spectrometry technique; Platinum

Authors: Shah K., Dhuldhoya N.
Title: Integrate LNG terminal with power plant to achieve BTU control and efficiency enhancement
Source title: 2006 AIChE Spring Annual Meeting

Abstract: EIA estimates natural gas consumption in the US at ∼ 22 tcf for 2004. EIA also forecast the US consumption for natural gas to increase to 26 tcf in 2010 and further increase to ∼ 31 tcf by 2025. A discussion on the integration of a LNG terminal with a power plant covers pipeline gas quality issues associated with imported LNG high heating values; future reduction in CO2 emissions; space requirements for additional equipment in the terminal, LPG storage, loading, and transportation to the local market or outside the region; determining commercial and technical feasibility; and economic aspects. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2006 AIChE Spring National Meeting (Orlando, FL 4/23-27/2006).

Authors: Shao J., Lu W., Lü X., Yue F., Li Z., Guo S., Chu J.
Title: Modulated photoluminescence spectroscopy with a step-scan Fourier transform infrared spectrometer
Source title: Review of Scientific Instruments
Affiliations: National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Shao, J., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Lu, W., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Lü, X., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Yue, F., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Li, Z., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Guo, S., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China; Chu, J., National Laboratory for Infrared Physics, Shanghai Institute of Technical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 200083 Shanghai, China
Abstract: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer is a powerful tool for studying the photoluminescence (PL) properties of semiconductors, due to its well-known multiplexing and throughput advantages. However, it suffers from internal He-Ne laser disturbance in near-infrared and/or environmental background thermal emission in mid- and far-infrared spectral regions. In this work, a modulated PL technique is developed based on step-scan (SS)-FTIR spectrometer. Theoretical analysis is conducted, and applications of the technique are given as examples in the PL study of mid-infrared HgCdTe thin films and near-infrared GaInP/AlGaInP multiple quantum wells, respectively. The results indicate that the He-Ne laser and/or thermal emission disturbance can be reduced at least 1/1000 and/or even 1/10 000, respectively, by the modulated SS-FTIR PL technique, and hence a rather smooth PL spectrum can be obtained even under room temperature for HgCdTe thin films. A brief comparison is given of this technique with previously reported phase-sensitive modulation methods based on conventional rapid-scan (RS)-FTIR spectrometer, and the advantages of this technique over the former RS-FTIR-based ones are emphasized. © 2006 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; Helium; Laser applications; Neon; Photoluminescence; Semiconducting gallium compounds; Semiconductor quantum wells; Thin films; Laser disturbance; Phase-sensitive modulation; Photoluminescence spectroscopy; Thermal emission; Infrared spectrometers

Authors: Sharif M., Ahmad S., Zakaullah M., Hussain S., Waheed A.
Title: X-ray emission scaling law from a plasma focus with different anode tip materials (Cu, Mo, and W)
Source title: Journal of Applied Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, 45320 Islamabad, Pakistan; Department of Physics, University of Sargodha, 40100 Sargodha, Pakistan; PINSTECH, P.O. Box 1331, 44000 Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Sharif, M., Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, 45320 Islamabad, Pakistan; Ahmad, S., Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, 45320 Islamabad, Pakistan; Zakaullah, M., Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, 45320 Islamabad, Pakistan; Hussain, S., Department of Physics, University of Sargodha, 40100 Sargodha, Pakistan; Waheed, A., PINSTECH, P.O. Box 1331, 44000 Islamabad, Pakistan
Abstract: X-ray emission from a 2.3-5.3 kJ Mather-type plasma focus [Phys. Fluids 7, 5 (1964)] employing copper, molybdenum, and tungsten anode tip is studied. Argon is used as a working gas. Characteristic Cu Kα and Mo K -series emission and their ratio to the continuous x-rays are determined. From the variation of the x-ray yield data with filling pressure at different charging voltages, scaling laws are obtained. X-ray pinhole images demonstrate that a significant amount of x-ray emission is from the anode tip. The comparison of the ratio of characteristic to continuum radiation for copper anode with typical x-ray tube data reveals that the contribution of very high energy electron beam from the focus region for x-ray generation through thick target bremsstrahlung mechanism is not significant. Rather, electrons with energy of the order of, or even less than, the charging voltage are responsible for bulk of the x-ray emission. © 2006 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Continuum radiation; Filling pressure; X-ray emission; Anodes; Continuum mechanics; Electric potential; Energy transfer; Image processing; Plasmas; X ray analysis

Authors: Sharma R.
Title: Infrared imaging camera use in the petrochemical industry
Source title: Air and Waste Management Association - Mini-Symposium on Smart Leak Detection and Repair 2006, At A and WMA's 99th Annual Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Lyondell Chemical Company, 1221 McKinney Street, Houston, TX 77010, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, R., Lyondell Chemical Company, 1221 McKinney Street, Houston, TX 77010, United States
Abstract: Use of the IR camera is increasing in the chemical manufacturing and refinery industries to detect hydrocarbon leaks from equipment. The IR camera can be an efficient tool that saves time and resources in detection of these leaks. IR cameras can also be used as a safety tool during facility start-ups, shutdowns, and maintenance turnarounds to check for hydrocarbon leaks. There are real emissions reductions being realized from this technology. Therefore, we must ensure that sound regulatory policy decisions are made and incorporated into the state and federal plans to reflect these reductions. To be sure, there are still challenges ahead for the use of the IR camera technology. Among these are the proper (quantification and speciation of leaks. We also need to gain regulatory clearance to use the technology as a substitute or alternative for traditional fugitive emissions monitoring.

Authors: Shavit Z.
Title: Fuel cell propulsion technologies and demonstration programs for fuel cell powered aircrafts
Source title: Technion Israel Institute of Technology - 46th Israel Annual Conference on Aerospace Sciences 2006
Affiliations: Israel Aircraft Industries, Engineering Division, Ben-Gurion Airport, 70100, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shavit, Z., Israel Aircraft Industries, Engineering Division, Ben-Gurion Airport, 70100, Israel
Abstract: Israel Aircraft Industries (IAI) wishes to demonstrate an all-electric mini-UAV powered by fuel cells (FC). The demonstration is intended to provide a proof of concept that fuel cell technology can be adapted to a wide range of future all-electric UAV designs. The advantages offered by fuel cells technology through an all electric or more electric aircraft are: high reliability, low maintenance, efficient propulsion, low noise and easy start up of engine. The mini-UAV specifications are: max payloads' weight of 8 kg, endurance of up to 6 hr, range 150 km, wing-span of 3.9 m, length of 2.3 m and speed range of 40 - 80 knots (74-148 km/h). In order to appreciate the advantages, a hydrogen fuel cell storage system with gravimetric efficiency of 6% provides a mass specific energy of 1100 Whr/kg, compared to 140Whr/kg for a rechargeable Lithium Ion battery. The fuel cell engine using hydrogen as fuel has an efficiency of approximately 60% compared to 30% when using an Internal Combustion Engine (ICE). The above advantages can increase, by factor of three, the fuel cells Mini-UAV's endurance relative to an electrically powered UAV that is based on Li-ion batteries. IAI is also involved together with other ten European organizations in the: ENvironmentally Friendly Inter City Aircraft powered by Fuel Cells (ENFICA-FC). It is a specific targeted research project (STREP) by the European R&D within the SIXTH FRAMEWORK. An all-electric propulsion inter-city aircraft (10-15 seats) or air-taxi aircraft (4-8 seats) could be completely equipped by fuel cells, realizing in such way a more silent and less polluting aircraft that will be able to takeoff and land from congested urban areas using short airfields. The project's main objective are to develop and validate through a flight test-bed the use of a fuel cells system as a power source for a more/all electric aircraft propulsion in order to eliminate or drastically reduce both pollutant emission and external noise.

Authors: Shaw R.
Title: The true costs of low carbon transport
Source title: IET Power Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, R.
Abstract: Carbon dioxide emissions from the UK transport sector are a growing problem because of the growing demand for road and air transport and continued dependence on fossil fuels. Some economic, social and planning changes to address the need to travel and the need for motorized transport are required to change the long-term environmental and social impacts. The government's 'Powering future vehicles' strategy aims for 10% of new car sales to have exhaust emissions less than 100g/km of CO2 with an associated target for low-carbon buses. LNG, hybrid and battery electric vehicles can bring benefits in terms of reducing noise and local pollution. There are a variety of ways in which electrical systems, particularly at the lower voltage distribution level, which may be called upon to support more sustainable transport. Battery electric vehicles have no exhaust, and hydrogen fuel-cell electric vehicles produce only water, thus reducing the carbon dioxide emissions.
Index Keywords: Air transportation; Environmental impact; Fossil fuels; Motor transportation; Particulate emissions; Social aspects; Carbon dioxide emissions; Fuel cell electric vehicles; Motorized transport; Social impacts; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Shellhorse V., Hoffmann J.
Title: Industrial size gasification for syngas, SNG, hydrogen and small power production using the BGL 1000 gasifier module
Source title: 23rd Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference, PCC - Coal-Energy, Environment and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Allied Syngas Corporation, United States; US Department of Energy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shellhorse, V., Allied Syngas Corporation, United States; Hoffmann, J., US Department of Energy, United States
Abstract: Industry is the largest and most diverse energy-consuming sector in the United States, using over one-third of all the energy consumed. Most of the energy industry uses is supplied by natural gas and petroleum products, with electricity a distant third. Based on the 2002 EIA Manufacturing Energy Consumption Survey, industry consumed over 5.7 quads of natural gas and over 964,000 GW-hrs (3.3 quads) of electricity. About 134,000 GW-hrs of electricity was generated on-site by industry. With the current high price of natural gas and the projected volatility in natural gas prices in years to come, industry benefits from an abundant, stable cost, reliable energy source. Coal has the potential of meeting this need through the use of efficient, industrial size gasification technologies. This paper explores the potential of the British Gas Lurgi (BGL) 1000 fixed bed gasification technology to supply industry with clean fuel gas from coal economically and with virtually no increase in industrial plant air emissions. The features of the BGL 1000 technology that make it particularly attractive for industrial application include: A single module producing about 1000 million Btu/hr of a clean synthetic fuel gas, a size applicable to a large number of industrial plants. Modular in design for small and medium size power applications in the 80 MWe to 250 MWe range. Capability of processing essentially all U.S. coals and many opportunity fuels including Eastern bituminous, Western sub-bituminous, and lignite coals; petcoke, biomass, TDF, and other potential fuels whether non-caking or strongly caking, with low or high ash fusion temperature, or having high sulfur, moisture, or mercury content. Utilization of solid fuels in the 1/4 to 2 size range, typical of as-received coals, with minimal preparation (i.e. no drying, pulverizing or slurrying). Demonstrated high cold gas efficiency (88 to 92%) among the best of commercial gasification technologies, with low specific consumption of oxygen and steam. Designed for very low environmental emissions practically no SOx or particulate emissions; greater than 90% mercury removal; non-leachable slag; and environmental performance unaffected by input quality.
Index Keywords: Coal gasification; Electricity; Energy utilization; Gas emissions; Lignite; British Gas Lurgi (BGL); Cold gas efficiency; Environmental emissions; Coal gas

Authors: Shen W., Zhang A.-L., Han W.-J.
Title: Alternative vehicle fuels strategy in China: Well-to-wheel analysis on energy use and greenhouse gases emission
Source title: Proceedings of 2006 International Conference on Management Science and Engineering, ICMSE'06 (13th)
Affiliations: School of Public Policy and Management, Tsinghua University, 100084, China; Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, Tsinghua University, 100084, China; Ford Motor Companies, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shen, W., School of Public Policy and Management, Tsinghua University, 100084, China; Zhang, A.-L., Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, Tsinghua University, 100084, China; Han, W.-J., Ford Motor Companies, United States
Abstract: Oil consumption and import of China increase very quickly in recent years. Because of vehicle population growing in a tremendous speed, nearly 40% of oil has already used in transportation sector in today's China. Many kinds of alternative fuel vehicles are introduced, demonstrated and used in cities to reduce the traditional gasoline and diesel not only to reduce the regulated emissions, but also to improve the oil security of China. When the Kyoto Protocol became effective in last year, Chinese government and experts began to focus on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of alternative vehicle fuels. In order to comprehensively evaluating energy and Global Warming impact lead by production and utilization of Alternative vehicle fuels in China, Well-to-Wheel analysis is used in this paper to quantitatively calculate energy use and GHG emissions of recovery, production, transportation and distribution, and end-use of compressed natural gas (CNG), liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), ethanol, methanol, dimethyl ether (DME) and Fischer- Tropsch diesel (FTD). The feedstock of ethanol includes corn and wheat. The energy use and GHG emissions of alternative vehicle fuels are compared with traditional gasoline and diesel. The results show that CNG and LPG is good choice from energy saving and GHG reduction in China. NG-based and coal-based methanol, DME and F-T diesel have lower lifecycle petroleum consumption than traditional gasoline and diesel, so that they may be an answer to Chinese oil security. The lifecycle total energy use, fossil energy use and GHG emissions of NG-based synthesized fuels are lower than coal-based fuels, but obviously higher than traditional gasoline and diesel, so that utilization of them will lead to potential pressure to China GHG reduction responsibility. The GHG emissions performance of China ethanol fuel is not as good as U.S. ethanol. The main reason is abuse of agriculture chemical in corn farming, especial the nitrogenous fertilizer, which is caused great N20 emission.
Author Keywords: Alternative vehicle fuel; Energy use; Greenhouse gases; Well-to-wheel
Index Keywords: Computation theory; Energy utilization; Gasoline; Greenhouse gases; Particulate emissions; Alternative vehicle fuel; Well-to-wheel; Alternative fuels

Authors: Sherman R.E.
Title: Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems (CEMS): Development and benefits of modular basis (ANSI/ISA-76) sample conditioning systems for USEPA 40CFR part 60 and 40CFR part 75 Emissions Monitoring and reporting
Source title: 16th Annual Joint ISA POWID/EPRI Controls and Instrumentation Conference and 49th Annual ISA Power Industry Division, POWID Symposium 2006
Affiliations: CIRCOR Instrumentation Technologies, Division of CIRCOR International, Inc., 521 North Raven Road, Shorewood, IL 60431, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sherman, R.E., CIRCOR Instrumentation Technologies, Division of CIRCOR International, Inc., 521 North Raven Road, Shorewood, IL 60431, United States
Abstract: Many hundreds of CEMS (Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems) were installed in the period 1970-2000 to meet the USEPA (United States Environmental Protection Agency) 40CFR Part 60 "Standards of Performance for New Stationary Sources" (designed to require BACT-Best Available Control Technology) and 40CFR Part 75 (mass emission rates of SO2, NO X and CO2 for Allowance Trading Programs) Emissions Monitoring and Reporting requirements. The stack gases that these CEMS have been monitoring contained sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen. When these chemical species combine with the condensate created by the cooling of the transported stack gas sample (intentional cooling or inadvertent cooling from poor sample conditioning) they create corrosive acids (sulfuric, nitric acids are the most commonly recognizable species with others created in the mixture). These acids combined with the (often) heated sample conditioning system components create a very corrosive atmosphere and environment. Many of these sample conditioning systems are in need of replacement to maintain the CEMS legislated performance characteristics. The modular (ANSI/ISA-76.00.02-2002) sample conditioning system performance-proven standardized concept provides a solution to replace the sampling systems which require replacement while allowing the analyzers and controllers (PC or PLC) that are currently functional to be kept intact and able to be re-connected to the modular sample conditioning system. The benefit of the modular sample conditioning system approach is the replacement sampling system can be prefabricated and will fit within the original sample system enclosure. If this original enclosure is severely corroded the modular sample conditioning system with its new enclosure will easily fit within the original confines of the existing sample system enclosure. Most modular sample conditioning systems only require about 30-60 percent of the space of a tubed-and-piped (legacy) sample conditioning system. Modular sample conditioning system technologies are an accepted and performance-proven technology in the Hydrocarbon Processing Industries (HPI) and Chemical Processing Industries (CPI) since prior to their standardization in 2002.
Author Keywords: Accounting; Analytical technology; ANSI/ISA-76; Calibration; CEMS; CPI; Emissions; Engineering; HPI; Miniature; Modular; MTTR; NeSSI; Sample conditioning; Span gas; Surface mount; Technology; Zero gas
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Carbon dioxide; Condition monitoring; Cooling; Nitrogen; Sulfur dioxide; Surface mount technology; Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems (CEMS); Sample conditioning; Surface mounts; Zero gas; Industrial emissions

Authors: Shipley R.A.
Title: Down the rabbit hole: The curious case of the Hazardous Waste Combustion MACT
Source title: A and WM, Annual International Conference on Incineration and Thermal Treatment Technologies, IT3
Affiliations: Attorney-at-Law, 10229 Crosscut Way, Damascus, MD 20872, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shipley, R.A., Attorney-at-Law, 10229 Crosscut Way, Damascus, MD 20872, United States
Abstract: The United States Environmental Protection Agency's rule regulating emissions from hazardous waste combustors - commonly called the Hazardous Waste Combustor MACT - was promulgated on October 12, 2005. It is the final source category to receive technology-based regulations under the Agency's National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP) program that started 16 years ago. During the past 10 years, the rule has been developed and debated, proposed and promulgated, challenged and vacated, resurrected by negotiation, re-proposed, and re-promulgated. After all this study, discussion, debate, review, and drafting, it should be authoritative and definitive. However, significant questions regarding the rule's legitimacy and legality still swirl around it. These issues arise from a steady barrage of court cases challenging many different MACT standards over the past 10 years. These cases resulted in court decisions invalidating the vast majority of the disputed rules, including the first promulgation of the HWC MACT. Due to ambiguity in the Agency's authority, the atypical nature of the hazardous waste combustor source category, and the court's difficulty understanding the Agency's complicated MACT setting process, fresh judicial challenges pose real threats to the viability of the new rules despite all of these efforts. The most troubling aspect of this curious circumstance is that any court decision regarding the newest MACT challenge may come after facilities have already upgraded units to comply with new standards, thereby forcing facilities to undertake additional upgrades in the near future. This will only be the latest chapter of an extraordinary rulemaking adventure.
Index Keywords: Emission Standards; Hazardous Air Pollutants; Environmental Protection Agency; Hazardous materials; Industrial emissions; Standards; Combustors

Authors: Shukla P.R., Rana A., Garg A., Kapshe M., Nair R.
Title: Global climate change stabilization regimes and Indian emission scenarios: Lessons for modeling of developing country transitions
Source title: Environmental Economics and Policy Studies
Affiliations: Public Systems Group, Indian Institute of Management, Vastrapur, Ahmedabad, Gujarat  380015, India; Reliance Industries Limited, Mumbai, India; UNEP Risø Centre, Denmark; Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India; National Institute for Environmental Studies, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shukla, P.R., Public Systems Group, Indian Institute of Management, Vastrapur, Ahmedabad, Gujarat  380015, India; Rana, A., Reliance Industries Limited, Mumbai, India; Garg, A., UNEP Risø Centre, Denmark; Kapshe, M., Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India; Nair, R., National Institute for Environmental Studies, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The global climate change stabilization regime will have a bearing on future emission pathways of each nation. Corresponding to a combination of stabilization targets and a future global socioeconomic and technology scenario, there are national emissions pathways that when aggregated would make the global regime most cost effective. The underlying hypothesis of this article is that the disaggregated national (regional) scenarios, with explicit inclusion of developing country dynamics in scenario constructions and modeling frameworks, would enhance the qualitative and quantitative understanding of emissions pathways and mitigation strategies compared with the present exercises. The scenario construction for India pays specific attention to developing country dynamics, including multiple socioeconomic and demographic transitions. The article also delineates the lessons for modeling of these transitions in developing countries. The emissions pathways discussion, to begin with, considers 100-year nonintervention scenarios. For the business-as-usual scenario, the optimal portfolio of mitigation interventions in India corresponding to 550ppm (by volume) global concentration stabilization is presented. In conclusion, the article asserts the need for realistic inclusion of developing country transitions in global scenarios and modeling exercises so as to improve the emissions assessments and delineation of mitigation strategies for stabilization. © 2006, Springer Japan.
Author Keywords: 550ppmv; Climate and development agenda; Climate change stabilization; Developing country transitions; Disaggregated national scenarios

Authors: Shukla S.P., Madhusoodana C.D., Das R.N.
Title: Honeycomb supports, filters and catalysts for cleaner environment
Source title: Key Engineering Materials
Affiliations: Ceramic Business Unit, Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd., Bangalore 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Shukla, S.P., Ceramic Business Unit, Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd., Bangalore 560012, India; Madhusoodana, C.D., Ceramic Business Unit, Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd., Bangalore 560012, India; Das, R.N., Ceramic Business Unit, Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd., Bangalore 560012, India
Abstract: The extruded honeycomb supports, porous filters and catalyst monoliths are innovative ceramic products used in environmental protection. The development and applications of these novel materials and products are mainly driven by the environmental legislation in the region, the availability of technology, the mass manufacturing facilities and the cost effectiveness. This paper highlights some of the recent innovations and challenges in ceramic materials and design, and our findings in systematic understanding and applications of the principle of fabrication of honeycomb ceramics for various air pollution control systems in India. The use of locally available platy kaolin and advanced extrusion process control using rheological parameters of the paste are advantageously adopted for production of thin walled and high thermal shock resistant cordierite honeycomb supports for catalytic converters. The low cost design of diesel particulate filter (DPF) with off board electric regeneration system is found to be very effective in reducing the particulate emission in urban transport buses and proven for more than 100,000 km on Indian roads. The Ti-WV based SCR catalyst extruded in the form of honeycomb using high surface area TiO2 has shown high NOx reduction in coal fired boiler exhaust. The preparation of high surface area honeycombs from activated carbon and zeolites with adequate mechanical strength opens up new application areas. Some of the case studies on the above products and applications are presented in this paper.
Author Keywords: Catalyst; Filters; Honeycomb; Monoliths; Pollution control

Authors: Siahmakoun A., Tang Y., Granieri S., Hoghooghi N., Teferra S., Sayeh M.
Title: Comparison of wavelength conversion in SOA and EDFA fiber ring systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Dept. Electrical and Computer Engineering, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, IL 62901, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siahmakoun, A., Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Tang, Y., Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Granieri, S., Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Hoghooghi, N., Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Teferra, S., Center for Applied Optics Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Tech., Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Sayeh, M., Dept. Electrical and Computer Engineering, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, IL 62901, United States
Abstract: We report on two types of wavelength conversion techniques that are based on gain saturation effect in semiconductor optical amplifier (SOA) and erbium doped fiber amplifier (EDFA). In these amplifiers the gain saturation occurs when the optical density at the gain medium is high enough to result in depletion of the population inversion by stimulated emission. In each case, the fiber ring laser is assembled using a variable fiber coupler, a narrowband optical filter and the gain medium. For external input power values higher than the determined threshold value of the ring resonator, the gain will be saturated. Because the wavelength of the external laser is different from the oscillating wavelength of the ring resonator, the optical power at the output of the resonator is drastically decreased (low-state). On the other hand, when the input of the external laser is below the threshold value the output power of the resonator increases (high-state). In our experiment the operating wavelengths of the ring resonators are 1314 nm and 1553 nm for the SOA and EDFA respectively. The input signal is modulated around the threshold value for frequencies of 20 MHz and 1 MHz and resonator lengths of around 8 m and 16 m for the SOA and EDFA cases respectively. Both systems exhibit high contrast modulation of 41 dB and 33 dB at the output port for the low/high states of the SOA and EDFA ring lasers respectively.
Author Keywords: EDFA; Fiber laser; Gain saturation; SOA; Wavelength conversion
Index Keywords: EDFA; Gain saturation; Ring resonators; SOA; Wavelength conversion; Density (optical); Fiber lasers; Optical fibers; Oscillations; Resonators; Optical frequency conversion

Authors: Siegell J., Ritter K., Taback H., Lev-On M.
Title: Cheaper, faster, and smarter: Next-generation LDAR programs
Source title: EM: Air and Waste Management Association's Magazine for Environmental Managers

Abstract: The new technologies that allow greater efficiency in monitoring large number of process piping components are discussed. These technologies allow more frequent emission monitoring at resonable costs and faster identification of components when applied to leak detection and repair (LDAR). Fugitive emissions are air emissions from locations other than stacks, vents, chimneys, or other fixed locations designed for releasing emission. The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has supported LDAR research and development. The instrument reading, called screening value, are measured in volume parts per million (ppmv). EPA and some state environmental agencies have established the levels of screening value in a range of 100 to 10,000 ppmv. US regulations to control fugitive emissions contain a provision allowing stakeholders to petition EPA to recognize alternative controls. The modern LDAR is using optical imaging instruments in helicopters to search for leaks in processing plants.

Title: Intrazonal agricultural resources in Kurzeme peninsula
Source title: Research for Rural Development

Abstract: The paper focuses on the exposition of the research results on agricultural resources in Kurzeme peninsula-climatic resources, qualitative evaluation of the land, condition of land amelioration, topographic resources, and structural breakdown of farm land by types of use. It is concluded that extremely various climatic and soil conditions govern in the region. The Southeast part of Kurzeme peninsula is displayed very favourably by the aggregate value of agricultural resources. Labour productivity in Kurzeme has been analysed as well.

Authors: Silva G., Guedes M.C.
Title: Bioclimatic architecture in East-Timor - A path to sustainability
Source title: PLEA 2006 - 23rd International Conference on Passive and Low Energy Architecture, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Instituto Superior Técnico, DECivil, Av Rovisco Pais, 1096 Lisboa Codex, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Silva, G., Instituto Superior Técnico, DECivil, Av Rovisco Pais, 1096 Lisboa Codex, Portugal; Guedes, M.C., Instituto Superior Técnico, DECivil, Av Rovisco Pais, 1096 Lisboa Codex, Portugal
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to provide a contribution to the definition of environmental design strategies applicable to East Timor architecture. In this way, it tries to identify sustainable constructive solutions that can be adapted to the local climate in order to produce buildings with a good environmental performance, and reduced energy consumption. To do so, a field study was carried out, involving the bioclimatic analysis of several types of architecture existing in the region, from the vernacular architecture and colonial buildings to the contemporary post-independence architecture. The weather in Timor is mainly hot, with small daily and seasonal temperature amplitudes, and high air humidity. Altogether, these factors determine the quality of human comfort. The thermal issue was therefore the main concern behind the search for architectural solutions, considering passive cooling design strategies aiming to reduce or simply avoid the use of air conditioning. The final result is a summary of passive design solutions that may present a significant contribution to a sustainable development of the territory.
Author Keywords: Architecture; Bioclimatic Design; Comfort; East Timor; Passive Design; Sustainability

Authors: Silver B., Boudreaux-Bartels G., Mederer H., Pasquerella L., Peckham J., River-Hudec M., Wishner K.
Title: A warmer climate for women in engineering
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Rhode Island, United States; Department of Psychology; NSF ADVANCE Grant Program, United States; Department of Sociology; Department of Sociology and Anthropology; ADVANCE Leadership Team; URI President's Commission on the Status of Women, Switzerland; Work/Life Committee, URI, Switzerland; Institutional Review Board, University of Rhode Island, United States; John Hazen White Sr. Center for Ethics and Public Service, United States; Department of Computer Science, University of Rhode Island, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering; Department of Oceanography, University of Rhode Island, United States
Authors with affiliations: Silver, B., University of Rhode Island, United States, Department of Psychology, NSF ADVANCE Grant Program, United States; Boudreaux-Bartels, G., University of Rhode Island, United States; Mederer, H., University of Rhode Island, United States, Department of Psychology, Department of Sociology, Department of Sociology and Anthropology, ADVANCE Leadership Team, URI President's Commission on the Status of Women, Switzerland; Pasquerella, L., University of Rhode Island, United States, Work/Life Committee, URI, Switzerland, Institutional Review Board, University of Rhode Island, United States, John Hazen White Sr. Center for Ethics and Public Service, United States; Peckham, J., University of Rhode Island, United States, Department of Computer Science, University of Rhode Island, United States; River-Hudec, M., University of Rhode Island, United States, Department of Chemical Engineering; Wishner, K., University of Rhode Island, United States, Department of Oceanography, University of Rhode Island, United States
Abstract: In 2000, University of Rhode Island (URI) President Carothers acknowledged, following an extended and sometimes acrimonious AAUP faculty union grievance process, that there had been a climate hostile to women faculty in the College of Engineering. The purpose of this paper is to describe the positive steps that were taken at URI subsequent to that grievance to improve the climate for women faculty in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) fields, and to place these steps within a framework for climate change. The paper starts with an overview of the percentages of women nationally in Engineering, followed by a description of the hostile grievance process that took place at URI. Next is a discussion of pro-active measures that were taken by many communities of faculty on the URI campus, including most recently, those of the ADVANCE grant funded by the National Science Foundation. These measures have been guided by a grounded theory approach to climate change that posits simultaneous change in individuals, interactional contexts, and institutional practices. As a result, URI has recruited a significant percentage of new women faculty in STEM fields in a relatively short time, and is working hard to ensure that they are retained. There have been many recent national initiatives to address the problem of the under representation of women in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines. It is well recognized that, beyond workplace equity, diversifying the practitioners in Engineering and other STEM fields will enrich these disciplines by bringing different perspectives, skills, and values to the fore, will help America remain globally competitive, and will more responsibly integrate Engineering practice with societal needs. Importantly, women and minority faculty also provide critically needed role models needed to attract and retain a more diverse student population. In Engineering, women comprise only about 20% of bachelor degree recipients, and are only 6% of full professors, 12% of associate professors, and 18% of assistant professors.[1] In addition to recruitment barriers, retention and advancement provide additional obstacles. Reduced tenure rates, slower promotion rates, inflexible and demanding work schedules that make balancing work and family difficult, heavy service and teaching loads, and a male-dominated, often hostile work climate that does not validate the needs or contributions of women participants all contribute to a higher attrition rate[2]-[5] for women than for men STEM faculty. The University of Rhode Island was representative of these trends until a series of events, culminating in the activities of the NSF ADVANCE program, provided avenues for positive change in the College of Engineering, which now serves as a model for diversity at the University. © American Society for Engineering Education, 2006.
Index Keywords: Climate change; Curricula; Societies and institutions; Students; Grounded theory; University of Rhode Island (URI); Workplace equity; Engineering education

Authors: Simon S.J., Austin F.
Title: Landfill gas to energy - Getting the go-ahead
Source title: Electric Utilities Environmental Conference, EUEC 2005: 8th Annual Joint EPA, DOE, EEI, EPRI Conference on Air Quality, Global Climate Change and Renewable Energy
Affiliations: Shaw Environmental, Inc., United States; Stone and Webster Management Consultants, United States; EMCON, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simon, S.J., Shaw Environmental, Inc., United States, EMCON, United States; Austin, F., Stone and Webster Management Consultants, United States
Abstract: Many landfill owners and developers agree that a landfill's "free," waste biogas should be converted into useful energy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and avoid fossil fuel use. However, the cost and approval process for a landfill gas (LFG) to energy project can be daunting. Based on the experience of the 250 LFG burning electric projects and other landfill gas projects in planning in the US, these relatively small, electric facilities are often riskier ventures and more marginally profitable than fossil fuel utility stations. This presentation will describe how the quality of LFG and its contaminants pose special permitting challenges for LFG to energy projects and how project proponents have addressed Federal air permit requirements; state and local emission and toxics programs; and energy industry requirements and regulations. Examples will show how permitting challenges and grid connection costs can force these small electric projects, often 1-4 MW, into on-site use or direct use in boilers. LFG energy projects may be setting precedents for approvals of other bio-fuel efforts as well. Because gas production tax credits are unlikely to be available for LFG in the future, strong support from the green credit programs may be needed for LFG electricity production to continue to grow and contribute to the renewable energy portfolios.
Index Keywords: Electric projects; Green credit programs; Landfill gas (LFG); Production tax; Biogas; Cost effectiveness; Fossil fuels; Greenhouse effect; Laws and legislation; Project management; Renewable energy resources; Waste management; Land fill

Authors: Simpson B.J.
Title: Reducing carbon dioxide emissions from UK road transport
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers: Municipal Engineer
Affiliations: School of Engineering and Applied Science, Aston University, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Simpson, B.J., School of Engineering and Applied Science, Aston University, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Several cases of extreme local weather conditions since the storms of October 1987 have served as reminders of some of the possible consequences of global warming, recently more usually, although less precisely, referred to as 'climate change'. Carbon dioxide emissions have been identified as the principal likely culprit and road traffic is the only major source from the UK which is increasing in amount. Local authorities may feel impotent to make a significant contribution to a solution, but example is a worthwhile motive. A local authority can contribute in several ways: implementation of improved vehicle technologies; adopting road speed limits and upholding them; promotion of driving styles which are more sensitive to their environmental effects and of improved vehicle maintenance; policies to change mode of travel and transport and to reduce the amount of travel by several means, including fuller use of vehicles. Many of the ways of reducing carbon dioxide discharges locally will have other environmental benefits. The implementation of cleaner travel lags behind the science to allow it; local authorities have an important role to play in reducing the gap. Average vehicle loadings are low, especially for personal travel; there is much scope for improved environmental performance, and for public transport there are issues relating to value for public spending. Reductions in the amount of travel can also contribute to several government policies relating to social exclusion, promotion of sustainable communities and supporting town centre activities.
Author Keywords: Environment; Transport management; Transport planning
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Public policy; Vehicles; Transport management; Transport planning; Carbon dioxide; carbon dioxide; emission control; global warming; local planning; pollution policy; road transport; traffic emission; transportation planning; transportation technology; urban policy; urban pollution; Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Western Europe

Authors: Singh P., Thalagavara A.M., Naber J.D., Johnson J.H., Bagley S.T.
Title: An experimental study of active regeneration of an advanced catalyzed particulate filter by diesel fuel injection upstream of an oxidation catalyst
Source title: SAE Technical Papers
Affiliations: Michigan Technological University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, P., Michigan Technological University, United States; Thalagavara, A.M., Michigan Technological University, United States; Naber, J.D., Michigan Technological University, United States; Johnson, J.H., Michigan Technological University, United States; Bagley, S.T., Michigan Technological University, United States
Abstract: Passive regeneration (oxidation of particulate matter without using an external energy source) of particulate filters in combination with active regeneration is necessary for low load engine operating conditions. For low load conditions, the exhaust gas temperatures are less than 250°C and the PM oxidation rate due to passive regeneration is less than the PM accumulation rate. The objective of this research was to experimentally investigate active regeneration of a catalyzed particulate filter (CPF) using diesel fuel injection in the exhaust gas after the turbocharger and before a diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) and to collect data for extending the MTU 1-D 2-layer model to include the simulation of active regeneration. The engine used in this study was a 2002 Cummins ISM turbo charged 10.8 L heavy duty diesel engine with cooled EGR. The exhaust after-treatment system consisted of a Johnson Matthey DOC and CPF (a CCRT®). Steady-state loading experiments at 20% load at rated speed were performed for different times in order to achieve three particulate matter loadings of 1.1, 2.2 and 4.1 grams of particulate/liter of filter. Active regeneration was carried out at three CPF-inlet temperatures of 500, 550 and 600°C to cover a range of temperatures and filter loadings for thermal regeneration. The dependent data of fuel usage, time of regeneration, mass of PM oxidized and maximum substrate temperature are presented as a function of mass loading and inlet CPF temperature. The results show that higher CPF-inlet temperature and particulate matter mass loading are more effective for regeneration of the CPF and lower fuel usage in grams of PM oxidized per gallon of fuel used whereas low temperatures and lower mass loadings were not as effective due to lower reaction rates. 90% of the HC from the diesel fuel injection were oxidized across the DOC while the other 10% were oxidized across the CPF under the test conditions. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Bandpass filters; Catalysis; Catalyst regeneration; Diesel engines; Diesel fuels; Exhaust gases; Fuel injection; Fuels; Particulate emissions; Passive filters; Reaction rates; Diesel oxidation catalyst; Engine operating conditions; Exhaust aftertreatment; Exhaust gas temperatures; External energy sources; Heavy-duty diesel engine; Steady-state loadings; Substrate temperature; Oxidation

Authors: Sirén M., Heikkilä J., Sauvula T.
Title: Combined production of industrial and energy wood in Scots pine stands
Source title: Forestry Studies
Affiliations: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Vantaa Research Unit, PB 18, FIN-01301 Vantaa, Finland; Finnish Forest Research Institute, Parkano Research Unit, Kaironiementie 54, FIN-39700 Parkano, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Sirén, M., Finnish Forest Research Institute, Vantaa Research Unit, PB 18, FIN-01301 Vantaa, Finland; Heikkilä, J., Finnish Forest Research Institute, Parkano Research Unit, Kaironiementie 54, FIN-39700 Parkano, Finland; Sauvula, T., Finnish Forest Research Institute, Vantaa Research Unit, PB 18, FIN-01301 Vantaa, Finland
Abstract: Neglecting precommercial thinning can result in a too dense stand with an uneconomic removal structure for industrial wood harvesting. In these stands energy wood thinning directing all thinning removal to energy use can be a reasonable alternative. The annual biomass potential of energy wood thinnings in Finland is 4 million m 3, of which 3 million m 3 is stem biomass and the rest is crown biomass (incl. e.g. branches). Majority of the energy wood thinning stands are dominated by pine. Harvesting costs of energy wood thinnings are high due to the high number and small size of removed trees. Thus state subsidies play an important role in the economy of harvesting energy wood from young stands. Possibilities to include energy wood thinning for a systematic part of forest management has been studied in Finnish Forest Research Institute with the help of Motti stand simulator. Results presented in this paper concern pine dominated stands. When energy wood thinning is a systematic part of forest management, precommercial thinning is not neglected, but a denser stand is left growing. Silvicultural recommendations of today advice to leave 2000 remaining trees after precommercial thinning. In energy wood thinning alternatives 3000 or 4000 trees per hectare were left growing after precommercial thinning. In energy wood alternative thinning from below with whole tree harvesting was carried out at dominant height of 10 or 12 metres and 1300 trees per hectare were left growing. These alternatives were compared with the practice of today aiming only industrial wood production, in which thinning from below and leaving 1000 trees per hectare was carried out at the dominant height of 11-13 metres. With combined production of energy and industrial wood a remarkable amount of energy wood can be produced without compromising the industrial wood production. The first industrial wood thinning is not necessarily replaced by energy wood thinning, as is mainly the case in stands where tending practices have been neglected. However, in first industrial wood thinning the harvesting conditions, highly influencing the harvesting productivity and costs, are better in the combined production alternative. This new practice gives us possibilities to produce energy wood and promote the energy and climate strategies of the state. Also other advantages like better quality of saw timber and employment possibilities can be reached.
Author Keywords: Energy wood thinning; Forest management; Motti stand simulator; Scots pine
Index Keywords: Pinus sylvestris

Authors: Skodras G., Diamantopoulou I., Sakellaropoulos G.P.
Title: Experimental study on the effect of pore structure and surface chemistry of activated carbons on mercury adsorption
Source title: CHISA 2006 - 17th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering
Affiliations: Chemical Process Engineering Laboratory, Dept of Chemical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; Laboratory of Solid Fuels and Environment, Chemical Process Engineering Research Institute, Thessaloniki, Greece; Centre for Solid Fuels Technology and Applications, Ptolemais, Greece; P.O Box: 1520, Thessaloniki 54006, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Skodras, G., Chemical Process Engineering Laboratory, Dept of Chemical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece, Laboratory of Solid Fuels and Environment, Chemical Process Engineering Research Institute, Thessaloniki, Greece, Centre for Solid Fuels Technology and Applications, Ptolemais, Greece, P.O Box: 1520, Thessaloniki 54006, Greece; Diamantopoulou, I., Chemical Process Engineering Laboratory, Dept of Chemical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; Sakellaropoulos, G.P., Chemical Process Engineering Laboratory, Dept of Chemical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece, Laboratory of Solid Fuels and Environment, Chemical Process Engineering Research Institute, Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: Combustion processes, such as coal-fired power plants and municipal waste combustors, are major sources of mercury emissions. Mercury emission in flue gases is of significant environmental concern because of its complex chemistry and extreme toxicity. The problem is particularly severe for elemental mercury (Hg°) in vapour since it cannot be effectively removed using current air pollution control devices, such as baghouses and electrostatic precipitators. Adsorption on activated carbons is an alternative solution capable of controlling gas-phase mercury emissions. The purpose of the current study is to evaluate the performance of activated carbons prepared from Ptolemais lignite and demineralised lignite, as well as sulphur-impregnated activated carbons, for gas-phase mercury adsorption. For the production of activated carbons, the demineralization technique was succeeded by a two-stage activation procedure: Pyrolysis under N2 flow at 900°C, followed by activation under CO2 or CO2/N2=25/75 v/v atmosphere at the same temperature. Sulphur impregnation was realized by high purity sulphur flakes at 600°C for 2hs. Samples have been characterized for their pore structure properties by employing physical adsorption methods, such as N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 298K respectively. In order to determine activated carbons surface chemistry, namely, the number and nature of oxygen groups presented in carbon matrix, basic-acid titrations based on Boehm method and TPD-MS experiments were performed. Mercury adsorption tests were realized in a bench-scale adsorption unit consisted with a fixed-bed activated carbon reactor. The main objective of this work is to identify relation between the resulted structural/chemical properties of activated carbons and the production conditions, as well as the investigation of pore structure characteristics, surface chemistry and sulphur addition impact on mercury removal. The results obtained in the previous study relatively with the preparation procedure of activated carbons from Ptolemais lignite and the textural / chemical characteristics of the resultant products have been reported. The obtained results revealed that activated carbons produced from demineralised lignite posses a high-developed micropore structure with increased total pore volume and BET surface area. These samples exhibit higher Hg° adsorptive capacity compared to the ones prepared from raw lignite. In all cases, mercury removal efficiency increased by sulphur addition due to the chemisorption mechanism. It was also found that the starting material properties and activation process affect the number and the type of the surface oxygen groups presented in the produced activated carbons. The modification of surface oxygen groups after mineral matter removal can be attributed to the release of phenols, carboxyls and lactones linked to calcium in raw lignite. Lactones and carbonyls that remain at 900°C activation temperature are considered as possible active sites that favour Hg° adsorption. In all cases, the increase of activation time resulted in smaller number of functional groups.
Author Keywords: Activated carbon; Mercury adsorption; Oxygen groups; Pore structure
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Coal combustion; Combustors; Mercury compounds; Pore structure; Elemental mercury; Mercury adsorption; Municipal waste combustors; Oxygen groups; Activated carbon

Authors: Smali K., Alain D., Detlef K.
Title: Hybrid modeling approach to predict gas turbine combustor performance
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Technology
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Laval University, Que., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Smali, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Laval University, Que., Canada; Alain, D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Laval University, Que., Canada; Detlef, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Laval University, Que., Canada
Abstract: The design of an advanced gas turbine combustor is challenging because of the conflicting requirements of combustion stability, efficiency, pattern factor, relight capability and pollutant emissions. Over the years, the combustion laboratories at Laval University have completed several experimental programs to characterize the operation of a typical gas turbine combustion chamber. The flowfield around the combustor is quite complex in that it includes swirl, regions of recirculation, fuel injection, atomization, fuel evaporation, mixing, turbulent combustion, pollutants emissions, with convective and radiative heat transfer processes. The phenomenological understanding of these processes is not well established. Using Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD), a parametric study has been undertaken to model the pollutant species and, specifically, the carbon monoxide formation and oxidation processes. As it is, CFD calculations of a large number of chemical reactions would be required to yield the correct heat release. For example, for hydrocarbon fuels, we must resolve a transport Equation for each species. The computational burden of doing so is presently unacceptable (high cost and long time for calculations) in the context of a complicated flow field and confining boundaries of the real gas turbine combustor. We are proposing in this work a hybrid procedure by which the CFD calculations are fed into semiempirical correlations to predict the emission, efficiency and temperature profile for the combustor. In fact the chemistry was uncoupled from the fluid dynamic and the analysis of Lean Blow Off (LBO) with a network of Perfectly Stirred Reactors (PSR) and Plug Flow Reactors (PFR) was addressed to respect the characteristic time modeling based on a phenomenological approach, the CFD providing local flow properties. To meet the future goals of reduced emissions produced by gas turbine combustors, a better understanding of the process of formation of various pollutants is required. Both empirical and CFD approaches are used to provide the exhaust concentrations of pollutants of interest, such as Carbon Monoxide (CO), with varying degrees of success. In the present work, a hybrid emission model simulating the combustor by a number of reactors representing various combustion zones is proposed. A LBO chemical kinetic scheme was used to provide the fundamentals to simulate the reaction progress. The model addresses the combined effects of spray evaporation and mixing in the reaction zone. The model validation included the utilization of a large data base obtained for a can combustor available at the Laval University combustion laboratory. With different operating conditions, a very good degree of agreement with the data was obtained for the temperature prediction using this hybrid model, and the trend for CO emissions was not as good at lower A/F ratio, but the prediction improved significantly at higher values (leaner conditions).
Index Keywords: Carbon monoxide; Computational fluid dynamics; Computer simulation; Gas turbines; Machine design; Combustion stability; Combustion zones; Hybrid modeling; Pollutant emissions; Spray evaporation; Combustors

Authors: Smiatek G., Steinbrecher R.
Title: Temporal and spatial variation of forest VOC emissions in Germany in the decade 1994-2003
Source title: Atmospheric Environment
Affiliations: Institute for Meteorology and Climate Research (IMK-IFU), Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, 82467 Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Smiatek, G., Institute for Meteorology and Climate Research (IMK-IFU), Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, 82467 Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany; Steinbrecher, R., Institute for Meteorology and Climate Research (IMK-IFU), Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, 82467 Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany
Abstract: Biogenic emissions are strongly governed by temperature and light. One key issue for air quality modelling is to quantify the emission source strength variation of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC) on different temporal and spatial scales. In Germany, this variation has been investigated for forests (the major source of BVOC) at country, state, and local scales over 10 years. Hourly emission rates for each vegetation period (April to October) from 1994 until 2003 were calculated in 10 km resolution. A database was compiled containing land cover, forest distribution, foliar biomass density, leaf area index (LAI) and plant specific emission potential. Meteorological input parameters were obtained using the non-hydrostatic meteorological mesoscale model MM5. The semi-empirical BVOC model (seBVOC) uses these parameters as input. SeBVOC considers in addition seasonality of the emission potentials, light extinction within the canopy as well as leaf temperature, air humidity, wind speed, and solar angle. The results show an average BVOC emission of 366 Gg, with 40 Gg isoprene, 188 Gg monoterpenes, and 138 Gg other VOC (OVOC), for the period 1994-2003. The dominating emitter type is Norway spruce (Picea abies) contributing approximately 40% to the total BVOC. In the years 1994-2003, the annual BVOC emissions varied in the range of ± 20 %. However, in specific episodes and at specific locations the variation is as high as 150% compared to average emissions. Also the BVOC composition emitted is location specific. Using a sensitivity analysis, the contribution of uncertainties in estimating foliar biomass, emission potential, as well as temperature to the overall uncertainty of calculated potential surface BVOC emission rates is addressed. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: BVOC; Emission modelling; Inventory; Isoprene; Monoterpene
