Authors: Smith J.S., Aggarwal V., Fine S., Smith J., Goldstein R.
Title: Landfill gas to electricity projects: A cost effective energy solution
Source title: Electric Utilities Environmental Conference, EUEC 2005: 8th Annual Joint EPA, DOE, EEI, EPRI Conference on Air Quality, Global Climate Change and Renewable Energy
Affiliations: ICF Consulting; U.S. EPA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, J.S., ICF Consulting; Aggarwal, V., ICF Consulting; Fine, S., ICF Consulting; Smith, J., ICF Consulting; Goldstein, R., U.S. EPA, United States
Abstract: Demand for renewable energy is growing rapidly and landfill gas (LFG) is considered an established, low-cost, reliable source of renewable power. LFG energy can be used to satisfy renewable portfolio standards as well as support consumer renewable power products. As a renewable resource, LFG provides both environmental as well as economic benefits. It is one of the most cost-effective forms of renewable energy on a levelized cost basis and as a baseload renewable, also provides full credit against reserve margins. Because it is one of the few renewables that reduces methane and NMOC emissions, it also has the potential to provide additional emissions credits from methane reductions at the landfill apart from the green attributes received from offset of grid electricity. Landfill gas based electricity projects have a proven track record of nearly 25 years and currently the installed capacity adds up to over 1,000 MW with individual projects as large as 50 MW. There are several financial and regulatory incentives available for LFGE projects at the state and federal level including the Section 45 tax credits that were recently reinstated as part of the corporate tax bill. US EPA's Landfill Methane Outreach Program estimates that there are still 600 untapped landfills with an electricity generation potential of 1,500 MW.
Index Keywords: Economic benefits; Electricity generation; Electricity projects; Landfill gas (LFG); Cost effectiveness; Electric power generation; Electric utilities; Environmental impact; Land fill; Project management; Regulatory compliance; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Smylie M., Robinson D., Harris B., Furry D., McRae T., Hinnrichs M.
Title: Evaluating the capabilities of gas-imaging devices for detecting fugitive emissions in petrochemical plants
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Environmental Resources Management, 1777 Botelho Drive, Walnut Creek, CA 94596, United States; ICF Consulting Inc., Fairfax, VA, United States; URS Corporation, Austin, TX, United States; Leak Survey, Inc., Early, TX, United States; Laser Imaging Systems, Punta Gorda, FL, United States; Pacific Advanced Technology, Buellton, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smylie, M., Environmental Resources Management, 1777 Botelho Drive, Walnut Creek, CA 94596, United States; Robinson, D., ICF Consulting Inc., Fairfax, VA, United States; Harris, B., URS Corporation, Austin, TX, United States; Furry, D., Leak Survey, Inc., Early, TX, United States; McRae, T., Laser Imaging Systems, Punta Gorda, FL, United States; Hinnrichs, M., Pacific Advanced Technology, Buellton, CA, United States
Abstract: The use of gas-imaging devices, which provide a real-time, optical image of a leaking component, is of particular interest to federal and state regulatory agencies, as well as the petroleum and petrochemical industries, as a means to more cost effectively and accurately identify leaking hydrocarbons that contribute to air pollution. Field evaluations have been conducted to gain insight into the application of gas-imaging devices for the detection of fugitive emissions of hydrocarbons from refinery and petrochemical plant process equipment and piping systems. An evaluation of four gas-imaging devices was conducted at two hydrocarbon plants located in the Houston/Galveston area on 2/2-4/2004. The cameras were selected for evaluation based on their state of development and the availability of prototype or commercial camera capable of field-testing at the time of the project. The objectives of the field evaluation were to determine the mass emissions rate for various gases that each device could detect under normal refinery/chemical plant operating conditions; and to document (as appropriate) the apparent impact of external factors such as distance, angle of view, background objects, hydrocarbon type, and meteorological conditions on the ability of the gas-imaging devices to detect fugitive emissions. The field study led to the discovery of 66 leaks at the two test sites. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AWMA's 99th Annual Conference and Exhibition (New Orleans, LA 6/20-23/2006).
Author Keywords: Fugitive emissions; LDAR; Optical imaging; Passive infrared

Authors: Sokolov V.M., Gorbenko V.V., Vinnik I.A., Mekhed O.M.
Title: Processing the Ni- And Cr-bearing oxidized scarfing granulates with liquid cast iron
Source title: 2006 TMS Fall Extraction and Processing Division: Sohn International Symposium
Affiliations: Gas Institute, National Academy of Science of Ukraine, 39, Dehtiarivska St, 03113, Kyiv, Ukraine; National Technical University KhPI, 21, Frunze Str., 61002, Kharkov, Ukraine; Physico-Technological Institute of Metals and Alloys, NASU, 34/1 Vernadsky Ave, Kiev-142, 03680, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Sokolov, V.M., Gas Institute, National Academy of Science of Ukraine, 39, Dehtiarivska St, 03113, Kyiv, Ukraine; Gorbenko, V.V., National Technical University KhPI, 21, Frunze Str., 61002, Kharkov, Ukraine; Vinnik, I.A., National Technical University KhPI, 21, Frunze Str., 61002, Kharkov, Ukraine; Mekhed, O.M., Physico-Technological Institute of Metals and Alloys, NASU, 34/1 Vernadsky Ave, Kiev-142, 03680, Ukraine
Abstract: The cost effective and environmentally friendly recycling technology was developed and tested. It enables utilization of the fine nickel-base superalloy scrap in a form of heavily oxidized scarfing granulates. The process of granulates generation was discussed in details. Their properties were investigated. The results of literature search showed anticipated sufficient improvement of the properties of cast iron by its alloying with the elements from the scarfing granulates. The novel alloying approach is based on the two stage reduction operation. Firstly the granulates were partially reduced in a solid state by their exposure with powdery carbon at the range of 1550 - 1700°C. Then the gotten product was efficiently introduced into liquid iron since it has a form of fine natural agglomerates for arranging the optimal conditions for reduction of the granulates. The thermodynamic evaluation demonstrates higher reduction efficiency of carbon and silicon dissolved in iron than of the same elements in a form of the separate phases. The considered process partially provides itself by energy since the reaction of reduction of the chromium oxide by silicon dissolved in liquid iron has exothermal character. The mostly complete extraction of Ni was received. The sufficient reclamation of Cr was gotten at the same time.
Author Keywords: Allowing; Cast; Elements; Granulates; Iron; Properties; Superalloy
Index Keywords: Cast iron; Granular materials; Oxidation; Reaction kinetics; Reclamation; Recycling; Chromium oxides; Liquid cast iron; Scarfing granulates; Scarfing

Authors: Son G.S., Gwak C.S., Choi E.R., Hwang C.W., Kim S.K., Bae K.K.
Title: PM reduction in diesel exhaust gases with a photocatalytic DPF reactor
Source title: SAE Technical Papers
Affiliations: R and D Center, Neophotech Inc., South Korea; GM Daewoo Auto and Technology, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Son, G.S., R and D Center, Neophotech Inc., South Korea; Gwak, C.S., R and D Center, Neophotech Inc., South Korea; Choi, E.R., R and D Center, Neophotech Inc., South Korea; Hwang, C.W., R and D Center, Neophotech Inc., South Korea; Kim, S.K., GM Daewoo Auto and Technology, South Korea; Bae, K.K., GM Daewoo Auto and Technology, South Korea
Abstract: The tightening of diesel emissions legislation throughout the EU and US is leading to the development of emission control devices to enable diesel engines to meet the standards. One system which has shown great promise in controlling PM emissions is Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF). Even DPF has showed good filtering efficiency, it has also lots of challenge for serial applications. One of the challenges is regeneration of filtered PM at urban driving condition. Since the temperatures are much lower than those of PM oxidation by itself. Active systems are proposed to ensure the regeneration along variable driving conditions. In this study, Photocatalyst-Plasma and Honeycomb (PPH) is proposed as an active and continuous regeneration system of DPF on the road. The results show a good feasibility of PPH system for PM regeneration with lower power consumption without an increasing pressure on the DPF. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.

Authors: Son P.K., Nakauchi T., Akiyama S., Kashiwaya Y., Ishii K.
Title: TTT and CCT diagrams and crystallization behavior of various slags
Source title: 4th International Congress on the Science and Technology of Ironmarking, ICSTI 2006, Proceedings
Affiliations: Hokkaido University, Japan; Nippon Steel Co.Ltd, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; JFE Steel Co.Ltd, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Son, P.K., Hokkaido University, Japan; Nakauchi, T., Hokkaido University, Japan, Nippon Steel Co.Ltd, Japan; Akiyama, S., Hokkaido University, Japan; Kashiwaya, Y., Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Ishii, K., Hokkaido University, Japan, JFE Steel Co.Ltd, Japan
Abstract: Recently, slags, which are by-products of iron and steelmaking, are utilized for several ways. Though the properties of slags are depending on a cooling process, it is not controlled and just carried out by two ways, water quenching and air cooling. The current cooling methods can not recover the sensible heat of slag having high temperature above 1500°C. Therefore the development of new cooling process for recovering the heat as well as the value added slag will be necessary for the CO2 reduction. From these purposes, the knowledge of the TTT and the CCT diagram makes it possible to control the slag structure in the course of heat recovery. In this experiment, by using the hot thermocouple technique, the TTT and CCT diagrams were measured for clarifying the crystallization behavior. The nose position of TTT for BOF slag was less then 1s, which meant faster crystallization rate. BF slag was around 2s which located at middle between mold slag and BOF slag. According to increase of basicity, the nose position moved toward short time region.
Index Keywords: Cooling methods; Cooling process; Crystallization behavior; Crystallization rates; High temperature; Hot thermocouple; Slag structure; Water quenching; Carbon dioxide; Cooling; Crystallization; Thermocouples; Waste heat; Slags

Authors: Souza A.T., Cardozo-Filho L., Wolff F., Guirardello R.
Title: Application of interval analysis for gibbs and helmholtz free energy global minimization in phase stability analysis
Source title: Brazilian Journal of Chemical Engineering
Affiliations: Faculdade de Engenharia Química, UNICAMP/FEQ/DPQ, 13081-970, Campinas - SP, Brazil; Departamento de Engenharia Química, UEM/DEQ, 87020-900, Maringá - PR, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Souza, A.T., Faculdade de Engenharia Química, UNICAMP/FEQ/DPQ, 13081-970, Campinas - SP, Brazil; Cardozo-Filho, L., Departamento de Engenharia Química, UEM/DEQ, 87020-900, Maringá - PR, Brazil; Wolff, F., Departamento de Engenharia Química, UEM/DEQ, 87020-900, Maringá - PR, Brazil; Guirardello, R., Faculdade de Engenharia Química, UNICAMP/FEQ/DPQ, 13081-970, Campinas - SP, Brazil
Abstract: The tangent plane criterion has become important for a correct solution evaluation phase and chemical of equilibrium problem. This method, applicable to single and multiphase systems, is mainly used for a single equation of state modeling all phases involved. The present work is mainly concerned with the application of interval analysis methods for global energy minimization in high-pressure phase stability problems. Two approaches are applied: (i) the Gibbs free energy global minimization under conditions of constant temperature and pressure and (ii) the Helmholtz free energy density global minimization under conditions of constant temperature and volume. Five case studies, one ternary and four binary systems, are analyzed in connection with the Peng-Robinson equation of state (PREOS) model. Five more case studies, for the CO2 + fra/w-2-hexen- l-ol system at high pressures, are used to compare different methods of phase equilibrium calculation with the approach using interval analysis. Finally, a complex system, clove oil + CO2, is analyzed. The results indicate that the interval analysis method is robust and reliable for all the problems studied.
Author Keywords: Gibbs free energy; Helmholtz free energy; Interval analysis; Mathematical modeling; Phase stability
Index Keywords: Free energy; Mathematical models; Optimization; Phase equilibria; Pressure effects; Interval analysis; Mathematical modeling; Multiphase systems; Phase stability; Gibbs free energy

Authors: Spencer J.G.
Title: US GHG project offsets: Viable, plentiful, cost-effective
Source title: Electric Utilities Environmental Conference, EUEC 2005: 8th Annual Joint EPA, DOE, EEI, EPRI Conference on Air Quality, Global Climate Change and Renewable Energy
Affiliations: Blue Source, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spencer, J.G., Blue Source, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Abstract: As state and regional greenhouse gas emission trading programs continue to evolve across the United States, we have observed that much of the underlying purpose and economic benefits available from utilizing the broadest possible sources of qualified offsets are being weakened by those responsible for structuring these programs. These unnecessary restrictions will result in a clear loss to all parties interested in the success of these programs. The likely reason for these restrictions is a lack of knowledge of the extent to which offset sources are available and the verification rigor for which these offsets can qualify. This paper would expose the scope of our experience in identifying, creating, verifying and registering offset projects located in the United States across several industries (many of which are talked about, but rarely proven up): transportation, real estate, food and animal processing, retail distribution, enhanced oil recovery, energy conservation management, etc. Our experience in aggregating tens of millions of tonnes of various offset types over the past 5 years has given us practical knowledge that enables us to identify overlooked offsets and lower the cost of verification without lowering the project standards for such offsets. Our discussion of aggregation opportunities in light of the environmental and economic goals of these emerging trading programs should reinvigorate the discussion of the importance of offsets and clarify the rationale for expanding available sources and uses of offsets in these state and regional programs. The authors' position is based on several years of experience in sourcing and aggregating offsets in partnership with industry-leading and Fortune 500 companies. The authors have 1) secured under exclusive supplier relationships over 250 million tonnes of emission offsets through 2012 and 2) delivered or contracted for delivery over 9 million tonnes of ghg emission offsets to large final emitters.
Index Keywords: Economic benefits; Emission reduction; Greenhouse gas emission; Air pollution control; Economic and social effects; Energy conservation; Environmental protection; Greenhouse effect; Regional planning; Industrial emissions

Authors: Spracklen D.V., Carslaw K.S., Kulmala M., Kerminen V.-M., Mann G.W., Sihto S.-L.
Title: The contribution of boundary layer nucleation events to total particle concentrations on regional and global scales
Source title: Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics
Affiliations: School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; University of Helsinki, Department of Physical Sciences, P.O. Box 64, 00014 Helsinki, Finland; Finnish Meteorological Institute, Climate and Global Change, Erik Palmenin aukio 1, 00101 Helsinki, Finland; Atmospheric Chemistry Modelling Group, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spracklen, D.V., School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, United Kingdom, Atmospheric Chemistry Modelling Group, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States; Carslaw, K.S., School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Kulmala, M., University of Helsinki, Department of Physical Sciences, P.O. Box 64, 00014 Helsinki, Finland; Kerminen, V.-M., Finnish Meteorological Institute, Climate and Global Change, Erik Palmenin aukio 1, 00101 Helsinki, Finland; Mann, G.W., School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Sihto, S.-L., University of Helsinki, Department of Physical Sciences, P.O. Box 64, 00014 Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: The contribution of boundary layer (BL) nucleation events to total particle concentrations on the global scale has been studied by including a new particle formation mechanism in a global aerosol microphysics model. The mechanism is based on an analysis of extensive observations of particle formation in the BL at a continental surface site. It assumes that molecular clusters form at a rate proportional to the gaseous sulfuric acid concentration to the power of 1. The formation rate of 3 nm diameter observable particles is controlled by the cluster formation rate and the existing particle surface area, which acts to scavenge condensable gases and clusters during growth. Modelled sulfuric acid vapour concentrations, particle formation rates, growth rates, coagulation loss rates, peak particle concentrations, and the daily timing of events in the global model agree well with observations made during a 22-day period of March 2003 at the SMEAR II station in Hyytiälä, Finland. The nucleation bursts produce total particle concentrations (>3 nm diameter) often exceeding 104 cm-3, which are sustained for a period of several hours around local midday. The predicted global distribution of particle formation events broadly agrees with what is expected from available observations. Over relatively clean remote continental locations formation events can sustain mean total particle concentrations up to a factor of 8 greater than those resulting from anthropogenic sources of primary organic and black carbon particles. However, in polluted continental regions anthropogenic primary particles dominate particle number and formation events lead to smaller enhancements of up to a factor of 2. Our results therefore suggest that particle concentrations in remote continental regions are dominated by nucleated particles while concentrations in polluted continental regions are dominated by primary particles. The effect of BL particle formation over tropical regions and the Amazon is negligible. These first global particle formation simulations reveal some interesting sensitivities. We show, for example, that significant reductions in primary particle emissions may lead to an increase in total particle concentration because of the coupling between particle surface area and the rate of new particle formation. This result suggests that changes in emissions may have a complicated effect on global and regional aerosol properties. Overall, our results show that new particle formation is a significant component of the aerosol particle number budget.
Index Keywords: aerosol composition; aerosol formation; anthropogenic source; boundary layer; concentration (composition); nucleation; regional pattern; sulfuric acid; tropical region; Amazonia; South America

Authors: Stachulak J.S., Conard B.R., Bugarski A.D., Schnakenberg Jr. G.H.
Title: DEEP project on evaluation of diesel particulate filters at Inco's Stobie Mine
Source title: Proceedings of the 11th U.S./North American Mine Ventilation Symposium - 11th U.S./North American Mine Ventilation Symposium 2006
Affiliations: Inco Limited; National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, Pittsburgh Research Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Stachulak, J.S., Inco Limited; Conard, B.R., Inco Limited; Bugarski, A.D., National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, Pittsburgh Research Laboratory; Schnakenberg Jr., G.H., National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, Pittsburgh Research Laboratory
Abstract: The objective of the Diesel Emissions Evaluation Program (DEEP)-sponsored project at Inco's Stobie mine was to conduct a long term field evaluation of diesel particulate filter (DPF) systems available to the underground mining industry. Some of the major issues studied were criteria for selecting the filter media, means of DPF regeneration, efficiency of DPF systems and the occurrence of unwanted secondary emissions, and reliability and durability of DPF systems. Nine state-of-the-art diesel particulate matter (DPM) filtration systems have been retrofitted to heavy-duty and light-duty vehicles and have been subjected to extensive long-term in-mine evaluation. Periodic efficiency tests were conducted at various stages of the study (2001,2002 and 2004) to establish in-use efficiencies and durability of the tested DPF systems. The results were used to assess the effects of the filter systems on the concentrations of particulate matter, nitric oxide, nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide in the vehicle exhaust. The variety of filtration systems and regeneration concepts used in this study offered the opportunity to investigate their advantages and disadvantages. This paper also offers a review of selected experiences with the installation and operation of the DPF systems on underground mining vehicles at the Inco Stobie Mine. © 2006 Taylor & Francis Group.

Authors: Stanwick P., Stanwick S.
Title: Reducing greenhouse emissions: A comparison of united states and australian multi-nationals
Source title: Problems and Perspectives in Management
Affiliations: Department of Management, Auburn University, United States; School of Accountancy, Auburn University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stanwick, P., Department of Management, Auburn University, United States; Stanwick, S., School of Accountancy, Auburn University, United States
Abstract: Is the global commitment to climate change really global? The focus of this paper is to examine whether firms are consistently global with respect to their commitment to reduce greenhouse gases. This paper examines whether multi-national firms display the same level of commitment to greenhouse gas reductions across countries by their participation in two voluntary environmental programs in the United States (Climate Wise) and Australia (Greenhouse Challenge). This paper will specifically address two research issues: (1) Do multi-nationals participate in voluntary sustainable programs? and (2) Are multi-nationals consistent in their commitment to sustainability? The results of this study show that multi-nationals overall had a low level of participation in country specific voluntary sustainability programs. However, there could be a number of alternative reasons for the low level of membership participation in these programs © Peter Stanwick, Sarah Stanwick, 2006.
Author Keywords: Greenhouse gas emissions; Multi-national firms; Stakeholder theory; Sustainability; Voluntary environmental programs

Authors: Starnes C., Wolff P.J.
Title: Not enough air - Struggling for full load
Source title: 16th Annual Joint ISA POWID/EPRI Controls and Instrumentation Conference and 49th Annual ISA Power Industry Division, POWID Symposium 2006
Affiliations: EPRI I and C Center, 714 Swan Pond Rd., Harriman, TN 37748, United States
Authors with affiliations: Starnes, C., EPRI I and C Center, 714 Swan Pond Rd., Harriman, TN 37748, United States; Wolff, P.J., EPRI I and C Center, 714 Swan Pond Rd., Harriman, TN 37748, United States
Abstract: Coal fired power plants that have been operating for several decades have required significant changes to their air gas systems to adhere to continually evolving emission regulations. These changes include the addition of selective catalytic reduction (SCRs), electrostatic precipitators, SO 2 scrubbers, and other changes in the flow path that occur due to various plant modifications. With the additional pressure drops caused by these changes, maintaining the required air flow to sustain full load can be problematic. This paper will present the results of a modeling study performed on the air supply system of a 200 MW pulverized coal fired unit. Pressure loss caused by the addition of an SCR on this unit, may reduce the capability of the air and gas system below full load capacity. This study investigates the effects of flow path modifications, leakage mitigation and air pre-heater fouling on gas flow rate. The study is based on a steady-state one-dimensional network flow model.

Authors: Stauber T., Zimmermann R.
Title: Electron-Phonon interaction in quantum dots: Beyond the independent boson model
Source title: Proceedings of the International School of Physics "Enrico Fermi"
Affiliations: Instituto de Ciencia de Materielles de Madrid, CSIC Cantoblanco, E-28049 Madrid, Spain; Institut für Physik, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Newtonstrasse 15, D-12489 Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Stauber, T., Instituto de Ciencia de Materielles de Madrid, CSIC Cantoblanco, E-28049 Madrid, Spain; Zimmermann, R., Institut für Physik, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Newtonstrasse 15, D-12489 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: We have presented a model that is suitable to describe the electron-phonon interaction in quantum dots and can be treated numerically exact. Thus we were able to compare the exact spectral function with the self-consistent first-order Born approximation. The first observation was that the exact spectral function consists of delta functions whereas the Born approximation gives a continuous spectral function. But even after an artificially broadening of the exact spectral function, striking differences remain which are due to the inability of the Born approach to exhibit all shifts and splittings in detail. As an alternative we propose an analytic solution which employs the coherent states for representing the electron-phonon Hamiltonian. The rotating-wave approximation allows to reduce the problem to an (infinite) number of decoupled 2 × 2 matrices. Close to resonance (zero detuning), this approximation works remarkably well. The appearance of Franck-Condon factors points to the great similarity of the electron-phonon interaction in molecules and quantum dots. We have also applied the above technique to a two-band model in order to describe linear optical properties of a single quantum dot interacting with LO phonons. The exact linear polarization and the corresponding absorption spectrum is calculated by diagonalizing the appropriate Hilbert space of four electronic levels and four bosonic modes split off from the full phonon modes via an orthogonalization procedure. Parameter values for CdSe QDs are used to describe realistic absorption spectra, and a comparison between resonant and non-resonant QDs is carried out. Signatures of the phonon bottleneck are found, i.e. a stronger quasi-dephasing for the resonant case, but this is not as dramatic as simple arguments using Fermi's golden rule for phonon emission would predict. © Società Italiana di Fisica.
Index Keywords: Fermi's Golden Rule; First-order Born approximation; Franck-Condon factors; Independent Boson models; Linear optical properties; Linear polarization; Rotating wave approximations; Single quantum dot; Absorption spectroscopy; Bosons; Delta functions; Electromagnetic wave absorption; Materials handling equipment; Polarons; Quantum optics; Semiconductor quantum dots; Electron-phonon interactions

Authors with affiliations: Staudt, J.E., Andover Technology Partners, 112 Tucker Farm Road, North Andover, MA 01845, United States; Khan, S.R., Office of Air and Radiation, United States Environmental Protection Agency, United States
Abstract: The United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) uses the Integrated Planning Model (IPM) to evaluate the capital cost and emission impacts of policies under consideration. The Coal Utility Environmental Cost (CUECost) model is a Microsoft Excel workbook that US EPA has developed for users to estimate environmental equipment cost using unit-specific information. Studies were undertaken recently to update the performance and capital cost factors contained in these two models for SO2 control technologies. The studies showed an improvement (reduction) in the capital cost of SO 2 controls for a given level of performance when compared to capital costs predicted by previous models. This paper discusses how the new capital cost algorithms were developed.

Authors: Stehlík P., Pavlas M.
Title: Waste to energy as a contribution to ravage elimination
Source title: WIT Transactions on Ecology and the Environment
Affiliations: Institute of Process and Environmental Engineering, Brno University of Technology, UPEI- VUT, Brno, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Stehlík, P., Institute of Process and Environmental Engineering, Brno University of Technology, UPEI- VUT, Brno, Czech Republic; Pavlas, M., Institute of Process and Environmental Engineering, Brno University of Technology, UPEI- VUT, Brno, Czech Republic
Abstract: The fact that mankind has been facing serious environmental and global problems during recent years is generally known and it is not necessary to emphasize it. However, every concrete way providing us with a method leading to elimination of the ravage of the planet represents a valuable contribution. This paper is aimed at renewable energy in terms of utilizing waste as alternative fuel. The benefit is quite obvious - waste is disposed and its energy content utilized. This approach is called waste to energy Currently, an increasing amount of waste produced (both municipal solid waste - MSW and industrial and/or hazardous waste - IHW) can be considered as a driving force for finding efficient ways for the thermal processing when waste is removed and at the same time used as a valuable fuel. It represents a challenge for potential investors and operators as well as researchers. It is necessary to take into account the following needs: waste disposal as a necessity waste-to-energy as the main aim limitations given by environmental legislation locality - big cities or villages An idea about building new regional Waste-to-Energy Centers (WTEC) is outlined. It is based on a convenient combination of experience, know-how and sophisticated approach. WTEC is equipped with: a unit for the thermal treatment of hazardous industrial wastes a unit for the thermal treatment of common MSW a special incinerator for the thermal treatment of sewage sludge if more waste water treatment plants are situated in the region a system for sorting and separation of wastes connected with a production of alternative fuels a system for utilizing ash and flying ash for secondary building materials WTEC has to be based on up to date technology which enables a further extension and innovation initiated usually by increasing population and standard of living as well as more and more sweeping environmental limits.
Author Keywords: Emissions reduction; Energy; Sustainable development; Waste
Index Keywords: construction material; hazardous waste; industrial waste; integrated approach; planet; renewable resource; research work; standard of living

Authors: Stephenson R., Price K., Hoy P.
Title: How MicroSludge can lower greenhouse gases at wastewater treatment plants
Source title: 2006 IEEE EIC Climate Change Technology Conference, EICCCC 2006
Affiliations: Paradigm Environmental Technologies Inc., 200 - 1600 West 6th Ave, Vancouver, BC V6J 1R3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Stephenson, R., Paradigm Environmental Technologies Inc., 200 - 1600 West 6th Ave, Vancouver, BC V6J 1R3, Canada; Price, K., Paradigm Environmental Technologies Inc., 200 - 1600 West 6th Ave, Vancouver, BC V6J 1R3, Canada; Hoy, P., Paradigm Environmental Technologies Inc., 200 - 1600 West 6th Ave, Vancouver, BC V6J 1R3, Canada
Abstract: Municipal biological wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) generate greenhouse gases (GHGs) in three main ways: (1) by consuming large amounts of energy from electrical and natural gas utilities to operate the plant, (2) by inherently generating CO2 that is lost to the atmosphere, and (3) by generating excess microorganisms that must be disposed of. Effective conversion of these microorganisms or "waste activated sludge" (WAS) to biogas in an anaerobic digester and converting this biogas to energy are the two most important steps that a WWTP can take to minimize its direct and indirect generation of GHGs. Maximizing biogas production can decrease a WWTP's reliance on non-renewable energy sources that generate GHGs as well as decrease the costs of purchased energy. Sludge that is not converted to biogas will lead to GHG emissions to the atmosphere. Therefore, minimizing the amount of residual sludge that must be hauled off site to be either landfilled, applied to agricultural land, or incinerated also minimizes GHG emissions. Conventional mesophilic (37°C) anaerobic digesters (CMADs) at municipal WWTPs are not efficient at converting WAS to biogas, achieving 15 to 30% volatile solids reduction of WAS in typical 15 day treatment times. They capture only a small fraction (15 to 30%) of their biogas potential, resulting in a large portion (70 to 85%) of biosolids that still require disposal. Pre-treatment of WAS is needed to improve the performance of anaerobic digestion. MicroSludge is a sludge pre-treatment technology that greatly improves the efficiency of anaerobic digestion of WAS. MicroSludge results in: (1) more recoverable energy from biogas being available and therefore less non-renewable energy required to operate a WWTP; (2) less residual solids requiring transport either to a landfill, land application site, or incinerator; and (3) fewer GHGs being generated from the fugitive emissions of less residuals. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Anaerobic digestion; Greenhouse gas mitigation; MicroSludge; Sludge; Wastewater treatment plants
Index Keywords: Anaerobic digestion; Biological water treatment; Carbon dioxide; Greenhouse gases; Wastewater treatment; MicroSludge; Waste activated sludge (WAS); Sewage sludge

Authors: Stodilka D.O., Gerger A.P., Hlad M., Kumar P., Gila B.P., Singh R., Abernathy C.R., Pearton S.J., Ren F.
Title: Alternative magnesium calcium oxide gate dielectric for silicon carbide MOS application
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Sinmat Inc., Gainesville, FL 32641, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stodilka, D.O., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Gerger, A.P., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Hlad, M., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Kumar, P., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Gila, B.P., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Singh, R., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States, Sinmat Inc., Gainesville, FL 32641, United States; Abernathy, C.R., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Pearton, S.J., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Ren, F., Dept. of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: Films of MgO and MgCaO ternaries were grown at low temperature as dielectrics on 6H-SiC by gas-source MBE. MgO grown at 300 and 400°C revealed crystallites textured toward the (111) orientation on SiC (0001). A solid-solution Mg.75Ca.25 ternary was grown having a minimal lattice mismatch and low root mean square (RMS) roughness of 0.5 nm. SiC pretreatments in UV-ozone reduced carbon contaminants on the surface of SiC, but resulted in the increase of fixed oxide charge in the oxide/SiC interface. Electrical breakdown fields >3.5 MV cm-1 and low density of interface states on the order of 1011 cm-2eV-1' were achieved for a Mg.75Ca.25O ternary grown at 300°C. These oxides are presented for the first time as low temperature alternatives to SiO2 gate dielectrics for SiO2 MOS applications. © 2006 Materials Research Society.
Index Keywords: Crystal orientation; Film growth; Gates (transistor); MOS devices; Silicon carbide; Thin films; Electrical breakdown fields; Interface states; Oxide charges; Root mean square (RMS) roughness; Dielectric materials

Authors: Storkenmaier F., Birnkammer M., Caldiero V., Manschitz M., Mazar B., Stöckl P., Finsterhölzl H., Tonhauser J.
Title: Multifunctional encapsulations of the power train
Source title: SAE Technical Papers
Affiliations: BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Storkenmaier, F., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Birnkammer, M., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Caldiero, V., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Manschitz, M., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Mazar, B., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Stöckl, P., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Finsterhölzl, H., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany; Tonhauser, J., BMW Group, Center for Innovation and R and D, Germany
Abstract: The BMW Group systematically develops heat management concepts for power train warm-up optimization, which result in reduced fuel consumption and emissions - beneficial for both the customer and local car legislations. This paper describes an approach to develop multifunctional encapsulations. Reduction of fuel consumption - the primary goal - can be attained by extending the cool down time of the power train after engine shutoff; this will increase the probability of having a warm engine at the subsequent engine start. In addition BMW's development process enhances emission as well as exterior noise reduction and passenger thermal comfort. The fuel consumption during warm-up was analyzed and the correlation between actual customer benefit and improvements, measured according to official testing procedures, were investigated. Therefore different encapsulation concepts are presented and discussed in the context of an entire vehicle heat management concept. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Engines; Fuels; Noise abatement; Bmw groups; Customer benefits; Development process; Down time; Engine start; Heat management; Testing procedure; Warm engine; Copyrights

Authors: Strandhagen E., Marcus W.A., Meacham J.E.
Title: Views of the rivers: Representing streamflow of the Greater Yellowstone ecosystem
Source title: Cartographic Perspectives
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR, United States; InfoGraphics Laboratory, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strandhagen, E., Department of Geography, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR, United States; Marcus, W.A., Department of Geography, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR, United States; Meacham, J.E., InfoGraphics Laboratory, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR, United States
Abstract: The utility of this time-series raster-based graphing technique is not limited to streamflow data; it may be applied to a variety of temporal data. Any type of time-series data collected in intervals such as months to years or minutes to hours may be plotted with this approach. Climatic and transportation data for example are complex datasets well-suited to be plotted as raster images to visualize multi-dimensional properties. In addition, statistical techniques exist for analysis of patterns on the raster hydrographs. Spatial pattern analysis permits quantifiable measurements and delineation of patterns on a raster image. FRAG-STATS, a landscape ecology public domain software application can compute patch-analysis statistics of these temporal graphs. Temporal graphs use coordinates to plot a pixel-based image of variables such as streamflow by applying sound cartographic theory of color schemes and data classification. The technique displays all data points simultaneously providing a powerful static representation and an alternative to map animation. This new pixel -based technique allows for increased visualization of time related factors for a wide variety of data exploration and cartographic representation.
Index Keywords: cartography; graphical method; map; spatial analysis; streamflow; time series analysis; Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem; North America; United States

Authors: Strom K.B., Papanicolaou A.N.
Title: Toward prediction of the spatial distribution of clusters in a watershed via geomorphic and hydraulic methods
Source title: River, Coastal and Estuarine Morphodynamics: RCEM 2005 - Proceedings of the 4th IAHR Symposium on River, Coastal and Estuarine Morphodynamics
Affiliations: Dept. Civil and Envirn. Engr., IIHR-Hydroscience and Engineering, University of Iowa, IA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strom, K.B., Dept. Civil and Envirn. Engr., IIHR-Hydroscience and Engineering, University of Iowa, IA, United States; Papanicolaou, A.N., Dept. Civil and Envirn. Engr., IIHR-Hydroscience and Engineering, University of Iowa, IA, United States
Abstract: Small-scale bedforms, or microforms such as particle clusters, have been shown to affect sediment transport and stream flow characteristics when present in laboratory experiments, and have been documented in various mountain rivers throughout the world. In addition to accessing the impacts on mean and turbulent flow, sediment transport, and aquatic habitat of clusters, there is need for a basic understanding of the hydraulic, sedimentary, and geomorphic properties prompting existence of clustered topography. With such knowledge we might be able to predict the onset of clusters in stream reaches and therefore watersheds. The present research aims at addressing this shortcoming through a field study on a mountain stream. Traditional geomorphic characterization of clusters and the site at which they were located was conducted. Five main types of clusters with differing visual and quantitative characteristics were identified; namely the comet, heap, line, pebble, and ring shaped clusters. Additionally, hydraulic characterization of a cluster at the study site was conducted using a 3D acoustic Doppler velocimeter to identify particular fluid signatures left by clusters. The investigation is then integrated with existing data in the literature to present a combined dataset of river slope and sediment d 84 where clusters have been recorded. Results show that clusters have been found in a wide range of slopes and particles sizes (0.004≤S ≤0.06 and in 50≤d 84 ≤500 mm), but are most likely to occur in cobble size sediment at slopes typical of riffle-pool to plane bed morphologies. We hypothesize that although cluster microform dynamics are an outcome of local sediment and fluid conditions, these local dynamics are in turn a function of the larger-scale watershed dynamics; as watershed and climate properties govern topography, sediment input, and hydrology of a local stream reach. Implications of these results and hypothesis suggest that given the proper input from remote sensing satellite data, we will be able to predict, in an average sense, where cluster bedforms will develop in a stream corridor/watershed. © 2006 Taylor & Francis Group.

Authors: Styles P., England R., Stimpson I.G., Toon S.M., Bowers D., Hayes M.
Title: The effect of vibrations from wind turbines on seismically sensitive critical installations
Source title: Near Surface 2006 - 12th European Meeting of Environmental and Engineering Geophysics
Affiliations: Keele University, United Kingdom; AWE (Blacknest), Germany; Hayes-McKenzie Partnership, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Styles, P., Keele University, United Kingdom; England, R., Keele University, United Kingdom; Stimpson, I.G., Keele University, United Kingdom; Toon, S.M., Keele University, United Kingdom; Bowers, D., AWE (Blacknest), Germany; Hayes, M., Hayes-McKenzie Partnership, Germany
Abstract: In order to meet Kyoto targets, the UK has set the challenge of reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 60% by 2050. Renewable energy, especially wind power, will be an important contributor with a target of 10% of energy from renewables by 2010. The Southern Uplands of Scotland offer a prime wind resource because of a large region of high topography, appropriate wind conditions and 2 Gigawatt of generating capacity is planned. However, the United Kingdom Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty seismic monitoring site (CBTB) is situated at Eskdalemuir in the Scottish Borders. Concern was expressed that vibration from wind farm developments might prejudice the detection capability of this facility. The Ministry of Defence placed a precautionary blanket objection to wind farm developments within 80 km of Eskdalemuir. In order to assess vibration levels a 10 station broadband seismic network and a 4 station infrasound network were established for 6 months at distances out to 20 km from a 26 turbine wind farm situated on very similar geology and topography to Eskdalemuir and the planned wind farm developments. The study has permitted the identification of the principal propagation mode for ground vibrations from wind turbines and enabled their characterisation.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Electric utilities; Geology; Global warming; Public policy; Seismology; Wind turbines; Broadband seismic network; Carbon dioxide emissions; Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty; Detection capability; Effect of vibration; Generating capacity; Ministry of defence; Wind farm development; Wind power

Authors: Suhrbier J.H., Porter C.D., Smith V.E.
Title: Combining transportation and growth management to accomplish air quality and other environmental objectives
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Cambridge Systematics, Inc., 100 CambridgePark Drive, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suhrbier, J.H., Cambridge Systematics, Inc., 100 CambridgePark Drive, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Porter, C.D., Cambridge Systematics, Inc., 100 CambridgePark Drive, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Smith, V.E., Cambridge Systematics, Inc., 100 CambridgePark Drive, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Abstract: A new approach to transportation planning is evolving where investment in roadway, transit, walking, and bicycling transportation infrastructure, and land use development decisions are made in conjunction with one another as part of a coordinated and integrated management decision-making process. The objective of these initiatives is to provide transportation mobility while simultaneously achieving objectives relating to growth management, land use, air quality, preservation of communities and the natural environment, and public health. A discussion on the initiatives conducted for the Federal Highway Administration, the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, and the EPA covers the Transportation and Community and System Preservation Program that enhance the linkages between transportation, housing, environment, economic development, and community livability; national site visits on transportation and growth; regional travel and emission impacts on reducing vehicle miles of travel (VMT) and emissions compared; and the characteristics that are critical to achieving successful projects, i.e., vision, leadership, partnerships, public process, technical resources, and implementation tools. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AWMA's 99th Annual Conference and Exhibition (New Orleans, LA 6/20-23/2006).

Authors: Sulatisky M., Hill S., Lung B.
Title: Dual-fuel hydrogen pickup trucks
Source title: 16th World Hydrogen Energy Conference 2006, WHEC 2006
Affiliations: Saskatchewan Research Council, 15 Innovation Boulevard, Saskatoon, SK, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sulatisky, M., Saskatchewan Research Council, 15 Innovation Boulevard, Saskatoon, SK, Canada; Hill, S., Saskatchewan Research Council, 15 Innovation Boulevard, Saskatoon, SK, Canada; Lung, B., Saskatchewan Research Council, 15 Innovation Boulevard, Saskatoon, SK, Canada
Abstract: Gasoline and diesel pickup trucks have been adapted to run on hydrogen utilizing dual-fuel electronic fuel-injection systems developed at the Saskatchewan Research Council (SRC). The hydrogen retrofit systems are designed for installation in General Motors pickup trucks equipped with the 6.0-L Vortec gasoline engine or the 6.6-L Duramax diesel engine. The vehicles can be operated in the dual-fuel mode or in the fossil-fuel mode when remote from the hydrogen fuelling station. Greenhouse gas emissions are reduced in proportion to the level of hydrogen substitution for fossil fuels, which is about 40 to 50% in normal driving. Emission tests in the hydrogen/gasoline vehicle indicate reductions in CO, NOx, and THC of 19 to 27%. In the diesel engine, tests indicate a 14% reduction in NOx emissions. The city and highway driving ranges on dual fuel are about 110 and 180 km, respectively. It is expected that the technology can be replicated on various engine platforms at a relatively low cost to help build hydrogen infrastructure.
Author Keywords: Diesel; Dual fuel; Gasoline; Hydrogen; Trucks
Index Keywords: Diesel; Dual-fuels; Fuel injection systems; Gasoline engines; Hydrogen fuelling stations; Hydrogen infrastructure; Normal driving; Saskatchewan research councils; Diesel engines; Dual fuel engines; Fuels; Gas emissions; Gasoline; Greenhouse gases; Nitrogen oxides; Trucks; Hydrogen

Authors: Sullivan L., Mark B., Parnell T.
Title: Lessons for the application of renewable energy technologies in high density urban locations
Source title: PLEA 2006 - 23rd International Conference on Passive and Low Energy Architecture, Conference Proceedings
Authors with affiliations: Sullivan, L.; Mark, B.; Parnell, T.
Abstract: This paper examines the commercial and construction-level applicability of a range of renewable (low or zero fossil energy) technologies to a project comprising 5 No 100 unit apartment blocks of new high density urban residential development. The paper addresses the level of carbon reduction compared to capital costs of all measures compliant with current British sustainable development planning policy. The paper sets out other non-planning compliant strategies in terms of carbon reduction compared to capital cost to determine if a prescriptive target setting policy approach leads to the most effective use of capital in achieving carbon saving. The paper also examines the architectural and ongoing building management implications of successful integration of such technologies, as well as the longer-term life-cycle considerations of the different technologies and the implications on life-cycle costs. The paper also makes firm suggestions as to the appropriateness of on-site methods of renewable energy generation compared to an auditable investment approach to off-site renewable energy generation.
Author Keywords: Density; Planning policy; Renewable energy

Authors: Sun L., Muto S., Tokunaga S., Okiyama M.
Title: Numerical Analysis of Environmental and Energy Policies Related on Automobiles in China : Evaluation by Dynamic Computable General Equilibrium Model
Source title: Studies in Regional Science
Affiliations: Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, Japan; Department of Civil Engineering Urban Design, Osaka Institute of Technology, Japan; School of Life Environmental Science, University of Tsukuba, Japan; Marketing Study Group, GENDAI Advanced Studies Research Organization, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sun, L., Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, Japan; Muto, S., Department of Civil Engineering Urban Design, Osaka Institute of Technology, Japan; Tokunaga, S., School of Life Environmental Science, University of Tsukuba, Japan; Okiyama, M., Marketing Study Group, GENDAI Advanced Studies Research Organization, Japan
Abstract: The Chinese government is examining to introduce some environmental and energy policies like as the fuel tax, mileage regulation or tax reduction to low emission vehicles, to the situation that the load rests upon environmental energy by the rapid growth of automobile market in Chinese. In this paper, we evaluated the environmental or economic impacts generated by introducing such environmental and energy policies by applying the dynamic computable general (DCGE) equilibrium model. From the results of numerical simulation, we obtained the some implications that the setting of high fuel tax level was necessary to regulate fuel consumption more effectively, mileage regulation was most effective policy to fuel reduction and the tax reduction like as Green tax or subsidy policy was necessity to change the type of car to low emission vehicles. © 2006, JAPAN SECTION OF THE REGIONAL SCIENCE ASSOCIATION INTERNATIONAL. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dynamic computable general equilibrium (DCGE) model; Low-emission vehicles; Tax reduction

Authors: Susuki Y., Yoichiro K., Kondo T., Moriya T., Shiino S., Mori K.
Title: Series hybrid electric drive system for city bus
Source title: 22nd International Battery, Hybrid and Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle Symposium and Exposition, EVS 2006
Affiliations: HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Susuki, Y., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan; Yoichiro, K., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan; Kondo, T., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan; Moriya, T., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan; Shiino, S., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan; Mori, K., HEV System Development Department, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, 10 Okura-Cho, Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan
Abstract: Series hybrid system is an ideal match for 'stop & go' city traffic with its smooth acceleration and higher energy efficiency thanks for braking power regeneration. [1] Also, as the engine can be driven at constant speed and power condition, it is possible to reduce exhaust emission using optimum tuning of engine parameters. Using these technological advantages, series hybrid city bus has been on sale from February 2004 as low emission and low fuel consumption vehicle [2] however, it becomes evident recently that more reduction on both exhaust emission and fuel consumption are requested to realize an environmental friendly society. To meet this social demand, the Ministry of Land , Infrastructure and Transportation (MLIT) started Next Generation Low Emission Vehicle Development Project conducted by the National Traffic Safety and Environment Laboratory (NTSEL) in 2002. This paper introduces the outline of the series hybrid city bus development within this project to fulfill the project target of low emission ( 75 % reduced from JP05) and low fuel consumption ( 50% reduced in city driving mode) . To realize these targets, the special diesel engine with new combustion technology, high efficiency all electric auxiliary drive system and high performance lithium-ion battery were developed and combined into the prototype vehicle. It was confirmed from vehicle test that the vehicle provided not only the low exhaust emission and fuel consumption but also the practicability as city bus. © EVS-22 Yokohama, Japan.
Author Keywords: A-1.2 hybrid electric vehicles; A-2.5 buses; B-4.5 li-ion battery; C-1.1 electric drive; F-1.1 series HEVs; Lithium ion battery

Authors: Sutton J.C., Sopher C.R., Owen-Going T.N., Liu W., Grodzinski B., Hall J.C., Benchimol R.L.
Title: Etiology and epidemiology of pythium root rot in hydroponic crops: Current knowledge and perspectives
Source title: Summa Phytopathologica
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Embrapa Amazônia Oriental, Caixa Postal 48, Belém, PA, 66017-970, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Sutton, J.C., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Sopher, C.R., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Owen-Going, T.N., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Liu, W., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Grodzinski, B., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Hall, J.C., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON  N1G 2W1, Canada; Benchimol, R.L., Embrapa Amazônia Oriental, Caixa Postal 48, Belém, PA, 66017-970, Brazil
Abstract: The etiology and epidemiology of Pythium root rot in hydroponically-grown crops are reviewed with emphasis on knowledge and concepts considered important for managing the disease in commercial greenhouses. Pythium root rot continually threatens the productivity of numerous kinds of crops in hydroponic systems around the world including cucumber, tomato, sweet pepper, spinach, lettuce, nasturtium, arugula, rose, and chrysanthemum. Principal causal agents include Pythium aphanidermatum, Pythium dissotocum, members of Pythium group F, and Pythium ultimum var. ultimum. Perspectives are given of sources of initial inoculum of Pythium spp. in hydroponic systems, of infection and colonization of roots by the pathogens, symptom development and inoculum production in host roots, and inoculum dispersal in nutrient solutions. Recent findings that a specific elicitor produced by P. aphanidermatum may trigger necrosis (browning) of the roots and the transition from biotrophic to necrotrophic infection are considered. Effects on root rot epidemics of host factors (disease susceptibility, phenological growth stage, root exudates and phenolic substances), the root environment (rooting media, concentrations of dissolved oxygen and phenolic substances in the nutrient solution, microbial communities and temperature) and human interferences (cropping practices and control measures) are reviewed. Recent findings on predisposition of roots to Pythium attack by environmental stress factors are highlighted. The commonly minor impact on epidemics of measures to disinfest nutrient solution as it recirculates outside the crop is contrasted with the impact of treatments that suppress Pythium in the roots and root zone of the crop. New discoveries that infection of roots by P. aphanidermatum markedly slows the increase in leaf area and whole-plant carbon gain without significant effect on the efficiency of photosynthesis per unit area of leaf are noted. The platform of knowledge and understanding of the etiology and epidemiology of root rot, and its effects on the physiology of the whole plant, are discussed in relation to new research directions and development of better practices to manage the disease in hydroponic crops. Focus is on methods and technologies for tracking Pythium and root rot, and on developing, integrating, and optimizing treatments to suppress the pathogen in the root zone and progress of root rot. © 2006, Universidade Estadual Paulista (UNESP). All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Brevipalpus spp; CiLV-C; CiLV-N; Citrus; Leprosis

Authors: Svandal A., Kuznetsova T., Kvamme B.
Title: Thermodynamic properties and phase transtions in the H2O/CO 2/CH4 system
Source title: Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Technology, University of Bergen, Allègaten 55, N-5007 Bergen, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Svandal, A., Department of Physics and Technology, University of Bergen, Allègaten 55, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Kuznetsova, T., Department of Physics and Technology, University of Bergen, Allègaten 55, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Kvamme, B., Department of Physics and Technology, University of Bergen, Allègaten 55, N-5007 Bergen, Norway
Abstract: The availability of free energy densities as functions of temperature, pressure and the composition of all components is required for the development of a three-component phase field theory for hydrate phase transitions. We have broadened the extended adsorption theory due to Kvamme and Tanaka (J. Phys. Chem., 1995, 99, 7114) through derivation of the free energy density surface in case of CO2 and CH4 hydrates. A combined free energy surface for the liquid phases has been obtained from a SRK equation of state and solubility measurements outside hydrate stability. The full thermodynamic model is shown to predict water-hydrate equilibrium properties in agreement with experiments. Molecular dynamics simulations of hydrates in contact with water at 200 bar and various temperatures allowed us to estimate hard-to-establish properties needed as input parameters for the practical applications of proposed theories. The 5-95 confidence interval for the interface thickness for the methane hydrate/liquid water is estimated to 8.54 Å. With the additional information on the interface free energy, the phase field theory will contain no adjustable parameters. We provide a demonstration of how this theory can be applied to model the kinetics of hydrate phase transitions. The growth of hydrate from aqueous solution was found to be rate limited by mass transport, with the concentration of solute close to the hydrate approaching the value characterizing the equilibrium between the hydrate and the aqueous solution. The depth of the interface was estimated by means of the phase field analysis; its value is close to the interface thickness yielded by molecular simulations. The variation range of the concentration field was estimated to approximately 1/3 of the range of the phase field. © the Owner Societies 2006.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; methane; water; article; kinetics; theoretical model; thermodynamics; Carbon Dioxide; Kinetics; Methane; Models, Theoretical; Thermodynamics; Water

Authors: Swartz M., Huff S., Parks J., West B.
Title: Intra-catalyst reductant chemistry and nox conversion of diesel lean nox traps at various stages of sulfur loading
Source title: SAE Technical Papers
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swartz, M., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; Huff, S., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; Parks, J., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; West, B., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: Due to increasingly stringent emissions regulations, Lean NOx Trap (LNT) catalysts are being researched as a potential solution for diesel engine emissions reduction. LNTs are practical for diesel NOx reduction due to their ability to reduce NOx from the O2 rich environment produced by diesel engines. LNTs function by storing NO x on the catalyst surface during efficient lean operation then, under rich conditions, releasing and reducing the trapped NOx. One method of producing this rich environment which regenerates a LNT involves manipulating the fuel injection parameters and throttling the air intake. This process is called in-cylinder regeneration. Experiments will be described here in which a 1.7 L common rail diesel engine has been used to regenerate LNTs at various stages of sulfur exposure, a known poison of the LNT. In-cylinder regeneration strategies were used to produce a range of reductant chemistries which enabled the study of the role of various reductants as NOx was converted across the LNT. This study gives insight into how to most efficiently regenerate the LNT. Sulfur poisoning of a fresh LNT was accelerated via the use of bottled SO2. Regeneration studies at various states of sulfation and after catalyst desulfation are discussed, highlighting intra-catalyst measurements of reductant chemistry and NOx conversion through the catalyst. Results showed that as sulfur loading increased, NOx conversion efficiency decreased and reductant utilization shifted downstream. Hydrogen from in-cylinder combustion was consumed over the first half of the LNT then produced from other available reductants over the last half for some strategies and conditions. Hydrogen production over the last portion of the catalyst was found to be affected by sulfur. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Air intakes; Catalysts; Emission control; Hydrogen production; Nitrogen oxides; Powertrains; Sulfur; Catalyst surfaces; Common rail diesel engines; Diesel engine emissions; Emissions regulations; In-cylinder combustion; Injection parameters; Regeneration strategies; Sulfur poisoning; Diesel engines

Authors: Szymczak M., Bartkiewicz A., Gérard E.
Title: EVN observations of an OH maser burst in OH17.7-2.0
Source title: Proceedings of Science
Affiliations: Torún Centre for Astronomy, Nicolaus Copernicus University, Poland; Observatoire de Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Szymczak, M., Torún Centre for Astronomy, Nicolaus Copernicus University, Poland; Bartkiewicz, A., Torún Centre for Astronomy, Nicolaus Copernicus University, Poland; Gérard, E., Observatoire de Paris, France
Abstract: We have observed the OH 1612-MHz maser emission towards the proto-planetary nebula candidate OH17.7-2.0 that underwent a very strong and unusual outburst in 2003. Phase-referencing data were obtained with the EVN in order to localize the outburst and to examine its possible causes. The majority of the emission comes from an incomplete spherical shell with inner and outer radii of 220 and 850 mas, respectively. There is a strong evidence for maser components that arise due to the interaction of a jet-like post-AGB outflow with the remnant outer AGB shell. The most prominent signature of such an interaction is the strongly bursting polarized emission near 73.3kms-1 coming from two unresolved components of brightness temperature up to 1011 K located at the edge of the biconal region 2500AU from the central star. It is remarkable that this OH biconal region is well-Aligned with the polar outfiow inferred from the near-infrared image. © Copyright owned by the author(s) under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike Licence.
Index Keywords: Infrared devices; Infrared imaging; Brightness temperatures; Maser emissions; Near- infrared images; Phase-referencing; Planetary nebula; Polarized emissions; Post-AGB; Spherical shell; Masers

Authors: Taback H.J.
Title: How "Smart LDAR" (leak detection & repair) evolved
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Hal Taback Company, 2703 Socorro Lane, Carlsbad, CA 92009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Taback, H.J., Hal Taback Company, 2703 Socorro Lane, Carlsbad, CA 92009, United States
Abstract: Beginning in the mid 1970s EPA and state agencies began to characterize the emissions from industrial processes and determine means to reduce those emissions. A research to measure the fugitive emissions from pipeline and equipment leaks in the petrochemical industry and the development of the techniques to control those fugitive emissions are presented. A research that analyzed 11.5 million leak-rate measurements is described and demonstrated that over 90% of the emissions emanate from only a few of the high-rate leakers and that those high-rate leakers are not chronic but occurs randomly from time to time throughout the plant. This finding led to the need for a method of searching for the high-rate leakers and repairing those leaks more frequently to reduce the period of leakage and thus the overall emissions. This concept was termed "Smart LDAR". As LDAR programs are currently conducted, nearly 1000 components are screening for every large leaker discovered. If a remote sensing instrument were used that could detect the high leakers and the frequency of detection could be reduced from the current quarter-annual period, the period of release would be reduced and a significant reduction in emissions would be made. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AWMA's 99th Annual Conference and Exhibition (New Orleans, LA 6/20-23/2006).
Author Keywords: Chronic leakers; Component screening values; Leak detection & repair (LDAR); Leak rate distribution; MACT rules; Remotes sensing; Smart LDAR

Abstract: The inclusive production of ω and mesons is studied in the backward region of the interaction of 12 GeV protons with polyethylene, carbon, and copper targets. The mesons are measured in e+e- decay channels. The production cross sections of the mesons are presented as functions of rapidity y and transverse momentum pT. The nuclear mass number dependences (A dependences) are found to be A0.710±0.021(stat)±0.037(syst) for ω mesons and A0.937±0.049(stat)±0.018(syst) for mesons in the region of 0.9<y<1.7 and pT<0.75 GeV/c. © 2006 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Takeshita T., Yamaji K., Fujii Y.
Title: Prospects for interregional energy transportation in a CO2-constrained world
Source title: Environmental Economics and Policy Studies
Affiliations: Department of Advanced Energy, School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takeshita, T., Department of Advanced Energy, School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Yamaji, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Fujii, Y., Department of Advanced Energy, School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a regionally disaggregated global energy model treating energy and CO2 transportation in detail is used to examine a cost-effective pattern for their interregional transportation over the 21st century under the CO2 stabilization target of 550ppm. Also, we assess future perspectives for the hydrogen economy in such a scenario. The results show that as major petroleum and gas supplies shift to unconventional resources along the second half of this century due to resource depletion, the Middle East loses its importance as a petroleum and gas exporter and the global patterns of their transportation change significantly. We then show that while hydrogen’s competitiveness decreases due to the detailed treatment of energy and CO2 transportation, biomass-derived Fischer-Tropsch (FT) fuels become attractive because their production facilitates a wide diffusion of CO2-neutral energy carriers by considerably reducing the transportation cost. FT fuels are produced in regions rich in forest resources and then transported on a large scale by tanker. By contrast, hydrogen is produced mainly at the center of its consumption regions using domestic feedstock, and its interregional delivery, which is done only by pipeline, plays a marginal role due to its high transportation cost. It is confirmed that such a hydrogen supply structure offers energy security benefits. Finally, we show that the regional distribution of CO2 storage capacity is a major determinant of the pattern of hydrogen transportation around 2100, because all the CO2 generated from hydrogen production is required to be captured for sequestration in that period and because interregional CO2 transportation is hardly chosen for economic reasons. © 2006, Springer Japan.
Author Keywords: CO2 concentration stabilization; Fischer-Tropsch synthetic fuels; Hydrogen; Interregional energy transportation; Regionally disaggregated global energy model

Authors: Takeshita T., Yamaji K.
Title: Potential contribution of coal to the future global energy system
Source title: Environmental Economics and Policy Studies
Affiliations: Department of Advanced Energy, School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Engineering, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takeshita, T., Department of Advanced Energy, School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Yamaji, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Engineering, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan
Abstract: Using a bottom-up type global energy model, this article explores in detail the potential role of coal over the 21st century and focuses on the prospects for coal gasification-based conversion technologies with CO2 capture and sequestration (CCS) under the CO2 stabilization target of 550ppm. The results show that even in the CO2-constrained world, coal can remain one of the important primary energy sources throughout the century on the condition that the resulting CO2 is properly captured and sequestered. Coal’s competitiveness in such a world would increase with the introduction of CCS, but decrease with the leak rate for CO2 stored underground. For the optimal coal use, a common trend toward producing convenient and clean final energy carriers via gasification is observed. Under the CO2 constraint, coal is increasingly converted via gasification with CCS into electricity and hydrogen, thereby providing CO2-neutral energy carriers and facilitating CO2 capture, which helps China and India develop in a sustainable manner. These findings prove to be robust with respect to the costs of gasification-based conversion technologies and CCS. It is suggested that the establishment of reliable CCS technologies and low-cost gasification-based conversion technologies and their transfer to developing regions would raise the value of coal and provide energy security benefits under the CO2 constraint. However, it is also indicated that large-scale introduction of coal with CCS into leaky reservoirs would cause large CO2 emissions from leaks over the very long term. © 2006, Springer Japan.
Author Keywords: Carbon capture and sequestration; Coal gasification; Global energy model analysis; Leakage of sequestered CO2; Synthetic fuel production

Authors: Tanabe J.
Title: Ironmaking mechanism by pulsed electric current sintered
Source title: 4th International Congress on the Science and Technology of Ironmarking, ICSTI 2006, Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nippon Institute of Technology, Saitama, 345-8501, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanabe, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nippon Institute of Technology, Saitama, 345-8501, Japan
Abstract: At present, the development of the ironmaking process based on the new principle which solves the problem of ironmaking process has been required. Then, the development of the ironmaking process at low temperature which is connected for energy saving and carbon dioxide reduction is noticed. In this study, mixed powder of iron sand and charcoal was made, and it was made to react by the pulsed electric current sintering (PECS) method in low-temperature (1373K to 1573K), and the steel was formed. Simplification, short time, low temperature were done in the ironmaking process of this study in the steel manufacturing. By the fact of the superscription, the region of the reaction of solid and liquid was utilized. The iron was formed on the temperature of 1473K, the proportion of iron sand and charcoal of 8:2 from 7:3, reaction time of the PECS methods at 0.6ks.

Authors: Tanaka R., Yamane Y., Sekiya K., Narutaki N., Shiraga T.
Title: Turning of BN free-machining steel
Source title: ICPMT2006 - Progress of Machining Technology - Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Progress of Machining Technology
Affiliations: Kanazawa University, Kakuma-machi, Kanazawa, 920-1192, Japan; Hiroshima University, 1-4-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; JFE Bars and Shapes Corporation, 1-6-1 Minato, Miyagino Ward, Sendai, 983-0001, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, R., Kanazawa University, Kakuma-machi, Kanazawa, 920-1192, Japan; Yamane, Y., Hiroshima University, 1-4-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Sekiya, K., Hiroshima University, 1-4-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Narutaki, N., Hiroshima University, 1-4-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Shiraga, T., JFE Bars and Shapes Corporation, 1-6-1 Minato, Miyagino Ward, Sendai, 983-0001, Japan
Abstract: This paper deals with the machinability of BN (Boron Nitride) free-machining steel in turning. Tested work materials were plane carbon steel JIS S45C and BN free-machining steel. The JIS S45C used as the standard. The tool wear in turning BN free-machining steel was smaller than that in turning standard steel. BN free-machining steel showed slightly lower cutting temperature and smaller cutting force to compare with standard steel at the tested cutting speeds. At the tool wear region of P grade carbide tool after turning BN free-machining steel at high cutting speed, Al and N were detected as a layer. It is thought that one of the main reasons of outstanding machinability of BN free-machining steel is the deposited layer containing Al and N acts as diffusion barrier at the tool-chip interface. In turning larger Al content BN added steel with higher Ti content cutting tool, the influence of BN addition on the tool wear reduction was more remarkable.
Author Keywords: Belag, AlN; Carbide tool; Cermet tool; Free-machining steel; Tool wear; Turning
